column1: 858185 § WONTFIX § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 22 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§This is new with the latest nightly build 22.0a1 (2013-03-15).  I have a Windows 7 (x64) PC with a high-res (200dpi) monitor and therefore have set text size 200% in Window's Control Panel.  With the 200% scaling
column2: in most applications fonts appear at the same size as they would on a 100dpi monitor under normal scaling.Therefore I would expect Firefox to work the same way
column3: with the default zoom level (View->Zoom->Reset) giving pixel sizes twice those you'd normally get (where 'normal' is a computer with the Windows font size set at its default 100%).§557§2§None§ 0§ 0§However
column4: in the latest nightly
column5: the fonts are even bigger than would be expected.  For example the Google home page is rendered so large that it doesn't fit horizontally even though the screen is 2400 physical pixels wide.  I suspect that the 200% scaling is being double-counted somehow
column6: so Firefox is now rendering everything at *four* times the number of pixels.</quote>The user there had the Default FullZoom Level add-on configured for a default zoom of 200% (as a workaround for the lack of proper resolution-dependent scaling in Firefox). With the landing of hidpi support
column7: this suddenly leads to 400% total scaling.The patch in bug 851520 will fix this issue for the case where the zoom level is being remembered in Firefox content prefs (i.e.
column8: we normally restore the zoom when the user returns to a site where they had previously zoomed in manually). However
column9: when an add-on such as Default FullZoom or NoSquint is used
column10: the add-on will reimpose -its- zoom level
column11: on top of the browser's default
column12: and so the user still gets oversized pages.To improve the user experience
column13: we may want to reach out to authors of such add-ons and recommend adjustments.(We could also consider "breaking" compatibility with them by modifying the API that is used to zoom
column14: but this would disrupt valid use-cases for the zoom API in addition to fixing the problem cases.)§1365§6§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #851520 +++From comment #0 there:<quote>§96§3 § +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #851520 +++From comment #0 there:<quote>Steps to reproduce:This is new with the latest nightly build 22.0a1 (2013-03-15).  I have a Windows 7 (x64) PC with a high-res (200dpi) monitor and therefore have set text size 200% in Window's Control Panel.  With the 200% scaling
column15: in most applications fonts appear at the same size as they would on a 100dpi monitor under normal scaling.Therefore I would expect Firefox to work the same way
column16: with the default zoom level (View->Zoom->Reset) giving pixel sizes twice those you'd normally get (where 'normal' is a computer with the Windows font size set at its default 100%).Actual results:However
column17: in the latest nightly
column18: the fonts are even bigger than would be expected.  For example the Google home page is rendered so large that it doesn't fit horizontally even though the screen is 2400 physical pixels wide.  I suspect that the 200% scaling is being double-counted somehow
column19: so Firefox is now rendering everything at *four* times the number of pixels.</quote>The user there had the Default FullZoom Level add-on configured for a default zoom of 200% (as a workaround for the lack of proper resolution-dependent scaling in Firefox). With the landing of hidpi support
column20: this suddenly leads to 400% total scaling.The patch in bug 851520 will fix this issue for the case where the zoom level is being remembered in Firefox content prefs (i.e.
column21: we normally restore the zoom when the user returns to a site where they had previously zoomed in manually). However
column22: when an add-on such as Default FullZoom or NoSquint is used
column23: the add-on will reimpose -its- zoom level
column24: on top of the browser's default
column25: and so the user still gets oversized pages.To improve the user experience
column26: we may want to reach out to authors of such add-ons and recommend adjustments.(We could also consider "breaking" compatibility with them by modifying the API that is used to zoom
column27: but this would disrupt valid use-cases for the zoom API in addition to fixing the problem cases.) § 2013-04-04T19:04:28Z § 2013-06-18T22:56:00Z

Selection Criteria

  • None
Selection Criteria
User-defined
  • BIA - All Regions - All Reporting Units
  • Fire Cause Natural

column4: Nightly 43.0a1 (2015-08-15))  Steps to reproduce:  1. Open new tab.2. Open Scratchpad (Shift+F4)
column5: paste "for(i=1;i<=12;i++)window.open('https://www.google.com/search?q='+i)" without outer quotes.3. Run script (so that popups opened and saved in History).4. Open new tab. Drag it from Tabs Toolbar to create new window.5. Click textarea in location bar [it will become focused]6. Press Alt+Down and hold for ~5 seconds7. That behavior will stay for that window even if you open new tabs.Expected result: It should display a box (#PopupAutoCompleteRichActual result) with scrollbar              where you only see 6 suggestions at a timeNote: It's a bit easier to reproduce on ESR38 - Beta41 (which don't have unified autocomplete). column1: 1633405 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Components § 7 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§There are a couple of GC options - dynamic heap growth and dynamic mark slice - that are enabled everywhere (although there are prefs to disable them).We should probably just remove these and simplify the code.One reason for disable the dynamic heap growth options is to make the GC more deterministic
column2: but we can handle that by never going into high frequency GC mode if JS_MORE_DETERMINISTIC is defined.§408§3 § There are a couple of GC options - dynamic heap growth and dynamic mark slice - that are enabled everywhere (although there are prefs to disable them).We should probably just remove these and simplify the code.One reason for disable the dynamic heap growth options is to make the GC more deterministic
column3: but we can handle that by never going into high frequency GC mode if JS_MORE_DETERMINISTIC is defined. § 2020-04-27T13:26:36Z § 2020-04-28T21:56:20Z

column4: so I'll illustrate with code:Say I have a link - BarAn image below the link - And then a named anchor - I want the link to direct the browser to scroll down to the named anchor. What ends up happening is the browser is directed to the image instead. I assume that this will happen with any object in the page that shares the same name/id was the image. Whichever object the browser encounters first will be where the link is directed to. Please view the above URL to see the problem in action.Now
column5: I was unable to find any information on standardization of object names and ids on the web
column6: so perhaps it's just bad form for a designer to name two different objects the same thing.  But testing this in other browsers
column7: I was unable to replicate the problem.  It may be that all the other browsers handle links to objects incorrectly and Firefox is the only one following standards
column8: I don't know.  I was always under the impression that an href could only point to a named anchor or another page

column1: 1639589 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§In the Kotlin language bindings core metrics are [initialized early](https://searchfox.org/glean/rev/fbe36bfe9758ac1ae8ac9047fb363b8e55db5cc5/glean-core/android/src/main/java/mozilla/telemetry/glean/Glean.kt#174) only if that's the first run
column2: otherwise they are [initialized later](https://searchfox.org/glean/rev/fbe36bfe9758ac1ae8ac9047fb363b8e55db5cc5/glean-core/android/src/main/java/mozilla/telemetry/glean/Glean.kt#210). This allows the previously stored "application" lifetime metrics to be consistent within the generated pings (even custom ones!).We need to make sure the behaviour matches with Kotlin/[Swift](https://searchfox.org/glean/rev/fbe36bfe9758ac1ae8ac9047fb363b8e55db5cc5/glean-core/ios/Glean/Glean.swift#111).§732§2 § In the Kotlin language bindings core metrics are [initialized early](https://searchfox.org/glean/rev/fbe36bfe9758ac1ae8ac9047fb363b8e55db5cc5/glean-core/android/src/main/java/mozilla/telemetry/glean/Glean.kt#174) only if that's the first run

This allows the previously stored "application" lifetime metrics to be consistent within the generated pings (even custom ones!).We need to make sure the behaviour matches with Kotlin/[Swift](https://searchfox.org/glean/rev/fbe36bfe9758ac1ae8ac9047fb363b8e55db5cc5/glean-core/ios/Glean/Glean.swift#111). § 2020-05-20T14:37:21Z § 2020-05-21T16:54:06Z

column1: 1642795 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Components § 32 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§People who have used OpenPGP in the past and who migrate to the new OpenPGP code
column2: will probably have verified some keys of other people. The usual mechanism to remember the verification is to use your own secret key to sign/certify that public key.Currently
column3: we won't accept those keys automatically
column4: they are treated as "undecided".This bug suggests to enhance our implementation in the following way:If we need to know the acceptance status of a public key
column5: and the key is still in the "undecided" state
column6: then perform an analysis of the certifications.For each certification
column7: check if it was made by any of the (still valid) secret keys that the local user has locally available. If yes
column8: and the signature is valid
column9: then treat the public key as "verified".Because this is an expensive operation
column10: we may cache the user's acceptance decision (in our sqlite table that's used to remember the user's acceptance decision).Once this is discovered
column11: we probably shouldn't allow the user to mark the key as "undecided" or "unverified" any longer. We might still allow the user to make the key as "rejected" (and figure out what action we should perform on the old key signature).It seems this is a very important functionality for anyone migrating.§1249§8 § People who have used OpenPGP in the past and who migrate to the new OpenPGP code
column12: will probably have verified some keys of other people. The usual mechanism to remember the verification is to use your own secret key to sign/certify that public key.Currently
column13: we won't accept those keys automatically
column14: they are treated as "undecided".This bug suggests to enhance our implementation in the following way:If we need to know the acceptance status of a public key
column15: and the key is still in the "undecided" state
column16: then perform an analysis of the certifications.For each certification
column17: check if it was made by any of the (still valid) secret keys that the local user has locally available. If yes
column19: then treat the public key as "verified".Because this is an expensive operation
column20: we may cache the user's acceptance decision (in our sqlite table that's used to remember the user's acceptance decision).Once this is discovered
column21: we probably shouldn't allow the user to mark the key as "undecided" or "unverified" any longer. We might still allow the user to make the key as "rejected" (and figure out what action we should perform on the old key signature).It seems this is a very important functionality for anyone migrating. § 2020-06-02T22:02:44Z § 2020-07-02T12:56:04Z

column1: 1569623 § WONTFIX § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § P5 § - windows 10- macOS 10.11- ubuntu 18.04§42§3§None§ 0§ 0§1. Setup the popub blocking policy:```{  "policies": {    "PopupBlocking": {	  "Allow": ["https://google.com"]
column2: "Locked": true    }  }}```2. Launch Firefox with a clean profile.3. Go to http://www.dummysoftware.com/popupdummy_testpage.html .4. From the yellow banner
column3: click the preferences banner.5. Choose to 'allow' the popups from the displayed drop-down menu.§383§15§- The user shouldn't be able to allow popups from other websites than the ones mentioned in the policy.§104§1§- The policy is bypassed and popups are displayed.[Regression range]:- I will invesitgate further
column4: but this does no look like a regression.[Additional notes]:- If the policy is deleted and the browser is restarted
column5: it can be noticed that the website was added to the exception list.- The fix from bug 1568246 was intended to deny access to the exceptions part
column6: but by using these steps
column7: the user doesn't even need access to the exceptions list to add in websites.§469§6§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§[Affected versions]:- Fx 70.0a1- Fx 69.0b9- Fx 68.0ESR§58§4 § [Affected versions]:- Fx 70.0a1- Fx 69.0b9- Fx 68.0ESR[Affected platforms]:- windows 10- macOS 10.11- ubuntu 18.04[Steps to reproduce]:1. Setup the popub blocking policy:```{  "policies": {    "PopupBlocking": {	  "Allow": ["https://google.com"]
column8: "Locked": true    }  }}```2. Launch Firefox with a clean profile.3. Go to http://www.dummysoftware.com/popupdummy_testpage.html .4. From the yellow banner
column9: click the preferences banner.5. Choose to 'allow' the popups from the displayed drop-down menu.[Expected result]:- The user shouldn't be able to allow popups from other websites than the ones mentioned in the policy.[Actual result]:- The policy is bypassed and popups are displayed.[Regression range]:- I will invesitgate further
column10: but this does no look like a regression.[Additional notes]:- If the policy is deleted and the browser is restarted
column11: it can be noticed that the website was added to the exception list.- The fix from bug 1568246 was intended to deny access to the exceptions part
column12: but by using these steps
column13: the user doesn't even need access to the exceptions list to add in websites. § 2019-07-29T14:47:09Z § 2019-10-23T19:18:22Z

column1: 1634191 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Components § 11 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Now that we've vendored `webext_storage` and have a shiny XPCOM component for our new Rust extension storage area
column2: let's make it implement `mozIBridgedSyncEngine`
column3: and wire up its methods to call into the `BridgedSyncEngine` on the Rust side. This depends on getting Mark's [sync infrastructure patch](https://github.com/mozilla/application-services/pull/2892) landed on the a-s side
column4: and bumping our vendored version to pick up those changes.While we're here
column5: we can also add a JS Sync engine for the new Rust extension storage.§531§2 § Now that we've vendored `webext_storage` and have a shiny XPCOM component for our new Rust extension storage area
column6: let's make it implement `mozIBridgedSyncEngine`
column7: and wire up its methods to call into the `BridgedSyncEngine` on the Rust side. This depends on getting Mark's [sync infrastructure patch](https://github.com/mozilla/application-services/pull/2892) landed on the a-s side
column8: and bumping our vendored version to pick up those changes.While we're here
column9: we can also add a JS Sync engine for the new Rust extension storage. § 2020-04-29T22:25:25Z § 2020-05-05T15:36:31Z

column1: 813892 § WONTFIX § blocker § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§I have a native extension (C++) for Firefox.I built it today against the latest XUL SDK (17) and it worked flawlessly in FF17 ESR but it didn't work good in FF17 Release.§172§2§My native extension should have worked in Release version as well.The release version should be built with the new XUL code and a new build should be released as soon as possible.§181§2§Query Interface didn't work good for various web elements like nsIDOMHTMLInputElement .After downloading source code of both Release and ESR builds I noticed that the guids of nsIDOMHTMLInputElement.idl are different:- ESR: e59a4df5-0904-414d-9203-9af2790698ea- RELEASE: 83984fd0-b0b2-11e1-afa6-0800200c9a66The difference is due to a change which fixed Bug 809865 ( https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=809865 ).It seems that the XUL code that the release version of Firefox 17 was built with is different (and older) than the code that the ESR version was built with (and after a little bit of checking it seems to be older than what Beta6 has been built with as well).§684§6§None§ 0§ 0§: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:17.0) Gecko/17.0 Firefox/17.0Build ID: 20121113065533§96§2§§0§0 § User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:17.0) Gecko/17.0 Firefox/17.0Build ID: 20121113065533Steps to reproduce:I have a native extension (C++) for Firefox.I built it today against the latest XUL SDK (17) and it worked flawlessly in FF17 ESR but it didn't work good in FF17 Release.Actual results:Query Interface didn't work good for various web elements like nsIDOMHTMLInputElement .After downloading source code of both Release and ESR builds I noticed that the guids of nsIDOMHTMLInputElement.idl are different:- ESR: e59a4df5-0904-414d-9203-9af2790698ea- RELEASE: 83984fd0-b0b2-11e1-afa6-0800200c9a66The difference is due to a change which fixed Bug 809865 ( https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=809865 ).It seems that the XUL code that the release version of Firefox 17 was built with is different (and older) than the code that the ESR version was built with (and after a little bit of checking it seems to be older than what Beta6 has been built with as well).Expected results:My native extension should have worked in Release version as well.The release version should be built with the new XUL code and a new build should be released as soon as possible. § 2012-11-21T09:16:45Z § 2012-11-21T16:10:10Z

1633505 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Client Software § 17 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§This work is being prioritized in order to help users who are trying to fix a problem with Firefox resolve issues. We see that a lot of users uninstall and then re-install Firefox (which does not actually do a refresh). Making it easier to fix corrupt profiles is something we'd like to include within the uninstaller.This will cover adding a refresh button to the first screen of the uninstaller

column1: 1640201 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 9 § P1 § (So for FOG for example the Upload Worker won't do much to start with (we haven't figured out the Lifecycle Design yet which impacts scheduling
column2: _and_ FOG shares a language with the core so there's no translation) and all the fun will happen (for now) in the Ping Uploader)§274§1§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§The [upload mechanism docs](https://mozilla.github.io/glean/book/dev/core/internal/upload.html) are very helpful in understanding the flow up to `get_upload_task` but not so helpful in understanding the expected way language bindings will interact with the task when they have one.§282§1 § The [upload mechanism docs](https://mozilla.github.io/glean/book/dev/core/internal/upload.html) are very helpful in understanding the flow up to `get_upload_task` but not so helpful in understanding the expected way language bindings will interact with the task when they have one.For instance
column3: TIL that we have a nice abstraction between a Ping Upload Worker and a Ping Uploader where the former takes care of language/platform/OS-specific things that aren't networking and the latter takes care of application-specific networking things.(So for FOG for example the Upload Worker won't do much to start with (we haven't figured out the Lifecycle Design yet which impacts scheduling
column4: _and_ FOG shares a language with the core so there's no translation) and all the fun will happen (for now) in the Ping Uploader) § 2020-05-22T15:24:32Z § 2020-07-14T15:42:17Z

column2: how long is default validity?* RSA or ECC? If RSA
column3: 3072 or 4096?There are good arguments for all choices
column4: so it isn't easy to make that decision.I'd prefer an expiration
column5: but suggest to use a longer expiration
column6: for example 3 years.We could use an RSA 3072 key for wider compatibility.§412§6 § Very soon we must decide what properties we should use for new OpenPGP keys by default:* expire or not expire? If expire

column9: so it isn't easy to make that decision.I'd prefer an expiration
column10: but suggest to use a longer expiration

959925 § FIXED § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 31 § P3 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Decoding and painting an image in pdf.js involves lots of copies of the data.(a) pdf.worker.js is a JS worker. It first decodes the colour data from the PDF    into an RGB array (24 bits per pixel)
column2: and the opacity data into an A array    (8 bits per pixel). These two combined are effectively copy 1.(b) pdf.worker.js combines the RGB and A arrays into a new RGBA typed array
column3: which has 32 bits per pixel. This is copy 2. Copy 1 is now dead
column4: and will    be reclaimed by the next GC.(c) pdf.worker.js transfers copy 2 to the main pdf.js thread. (This is a    transfer
column5: not a copy
column6: possible because it's a typed array.)(d) pdf.js does |d = createImageData()|
column7: which ends up in    mozilla::dom::CreateImageData()
column8: which allocates a Uint8ClampedArray. This    is copy 3. pdf.js copies the typed arrays (copy 2) into the ImageData (copy    3). Copy 2 is now dead
column9: and will be reclaimed by the next GC.(e) pdf.js does |putImageData(d
column12: which ends up in    mozilla::dom::CanvasRenderingContext2D::PutImageData_explicit.    (f) PutImageData_explicit() creates a new gfxImageSurface() and copies in the    data. This is copy 4
column13: and it is short-lived.(g) PutImageData_explicit() then calls CreateSourceSurfaceFromData()
column14: creating    a cairo surface. This is copy 5
column15: and it is short-lived. Copy 3 is now dead
column16: and will be reclaimed by the next GC(?)Each copy can easily be multiple MB
column17: and in the worst case (which is probablycommon) we have five copies of the data alive at once.So
column18: ways to improve it.- In steps (d) and (e) we can split the image up into smaller chunks
column19: and then  create/put those chunks one at a time. This will make copies 3
column20: 4 and 5 much  smaller.- In steps (a) and (b) it is possible to decode the data directly into the RGBA  array
column21: which would merge copies 1 and 2. However
column23: due to the  various kinds of colour encodings and the possibility of images being  resized.If we did both of those
column24: we end up with one full-size copy
column25: and three copies ofeach chunk
column26: but two of the copies of each chunk would be very short-lived.§2095§33 § Decoding and painting an image in pdf.js involves lots of copies of the data.(a) pdf.worker.js is a JS worker. It first decodes the colour data from the PDF    into an RGB array (24 bits per pixel)
column27: and the opacity data into an A array    (8 bits per pixel). These two combined are effectively copy 1.(b) pdf.worker.js combines the RGB and A arrays into a new RGBA typed array
column28: which has 32 bits per pixel. This is copy 2. Copy 1 is now dead
column29: and will    be reclaimed by the next GC.(c) pdf.worker.js transfers copy 2 to the main pdf.js thread. (This is a    transfer
column31: possible because it's a typed array.)(d) pdf.js does |d = createImageData()|
column33: which allocates a Uint8ClampedArray. This    is copy 3. pdf.js copies the typed arrays (copy 2) into the ImageData (copy    3). Copy 2 is now dead
column34: and will be reclaimed by the next GC.(e) pdf.js does |putImageData(d
column37: which ends up in    mozilla::dom::CanvasRenderingContext2D::PutImageData_explicit.    (f) PutImageData_explicit() creates a new gfxImageSurface() and copies in the    data. This is copy 4
column38: and it is short-lived.(g) PutImageData_explicit() then calls CreateSourceSurfaceFromData()
column39: creating    a cairo surface. This is copy 5
column40: and it is short-lived. Copy 3 is now dead
column41: and will be reclaimed by the next GC(?)Each copy can easily be multiple MB
column42: and in the worst case (which is probablycommon) we have five copies of the data alive at once.So
column43: ways to improve it.- In steps (d) and (e) we can split the image up into smaller chunks
column44: and then  create/put those chunks one at a time. This will make copies 3
column45: 4 and 5 much  smaller.- In steps (a) and (b) it is possible to decode the data directly into the RGBA  array
column46: which would merge copies 1 and 2. However
column48: due to the  various kinds of colour encodings and the possibility of images being  resized.If we did both of those
column49: we end up with one full-size copy
column51: but two of the copies of each chunk would be very short-lived. § 2014-01-15T04:28:03Z § 2014-01-25T13:17:56Z

column1: 444014 § FIXED § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 29 § -- § Otherwise useless information: for display profiles the ICC spec states that the wtpt tag should always contain XYZ values for D50. If the actual white point is not D50
column2: then the use of the chad tag is required. There are a number of malformed profiles that don't follow this esoteric and debatable rule in the spec. But the result is that it's possible to get chromatic adaptation between different white points where it is not desired. The simple logic is that the user is chromatically adapted to the display
column3: and further chromatic adaptation isn't needed
column4: which is what is implied by use of absolute colorimetric rendering.I'd recommend that contingency be made in coding for content and context specific rendering intents. For example sRGB images displayed to sRGB displays are best rendered using relative colorimetric. sRGB images for smaller gamut displays such as laptops are best rendered using perceptual. HDR images (when we get there) rendered to HDR displays are best rendered using absolute colorimetric
column5: etc. So boolean logic should be employed to get the best results. In the meantime we probably should use Perceptual.§1138§2§None§ 0§ 0§1. Install and set display profile using a profile with wtpt tag set to D50.2. gfx.color_management.enabled set to true and app relaunched.3. Open in Firefox a JPEG with embedded sRGB ICC profile intent flag set to absolute colorimetric.4. Open in Fiefox a duplicate JPEG with embedded sRGB ICC profile intent flag set to relative colorimetric§347§4§None§ 0§ 0§All other apps ignore this intent and use an intent appropriate for use of the image. For display
column6: Relative Colorimetric + Black Point compensation is what Photoshop does by default. Next most appropriate is Perceptual.Bug 418538 depends on this bug.§252§2§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10_5_3; en-us) AppleWebKit/527+ (KHTML
column7: like Gecko) Version/3.1.1 Safari/525.20Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9) Gecko/2008061004 Firefox/3.0In certain situations
column8: images will display incorrectly in Firefox even though they display correctly in other applications. This is primarily due to Firefox honoring the ICC profile intent flag. Specifically honoring the intent if set to "absolute colorimetric" rendering.If the intent flag is set to "absolute colorimetric"
column9: and the wtpt tag in the two ICC profiles aren't the same (i.e. wtpt XYZ values are D50 for display
column10: and D65 for the embedded profile color space)
column11: the image will shift dramatically blue or yellow. (D65 image to D50 display = blue shift; D50 image to D65 display = yellow shift).§846§4§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10_5_3; en-us) AppleWebKit/527+ (KHTML
column12: like Gecko) Version/3.1.1 Safari/525.20Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9) Gecko/2008061004 Firefox/3.0In certain situations

Open in Firefox a JPEG with embedded sRGB ICC profile intent flag set to absolute colorimetric.4. Open in Fiefox a duplicate JPEG with embedded sRGB ICC profile intent flag set to relative colorimetricActual Actual results:  Image with intent=absolute colorimetric will display bluer than it should.Expected Actual results:  All other apps ignore this intent and use an intent appropriate for use of the image. For display
column17: Relative Colorimetric + Black Point compensation is what Photoshop does by default. If the actual white point is not D50

But the result is that it's possible to get chromatic adaptation between different white points where it is not desired. The simple logic is that the user is chromatically adapted to the display

Open browser with that profile and attempt to modify Navigation toolbar.§237§4§None§ 0§ 0§Navigation toolbar should display as set.§42§1§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8b4) Gecko/20050908 Firefox/1.4Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8b4) Gecko/20050908 Firefox/1.4I created a profile in Firefox 1.5 B1 and moved it to another directory on mydrive.  I checked to make sure there were no hard references anywhere in theprofile.  To be sure I deleted the localstore.rdf and XUL.mfl files.I loaded up Firefox 1.5 B1 and everything appeared to be working until I triedto modify the Navigation Toolbar.  Any changes will stick in the current browserwindow
column2: but opening another window or closing and reopening the browser resultsin the Navigation Toolbar returning to its default state.  You can even end upwith multiple location drop down boxes if you move the location drop down box toanother toolbar and open a new browser window.When I moved the profile back to the default Profiles directory and changed theprofile.ini back to a relative profile
column3: then the Navigation toolbar displayed as I set it up.  This means that the localstore.rdf file is being set correctly
column4: but for some reason it is being ignored when read in on a non-relative profile.§1187§15§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8b4) Gecko/20050908 Firefox/1.4Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8b4) Gecko/20050908 Firefox/1.4I created a profile in Firefox 1.5 B1 and moved it to another directory on mydrive.  I checked to make sure there were no hard references anywhere in theprofile.  To be sure I deleted the localstore.rdf and XUL.mfl files.I loaded up Firefox 1.5 B1 and everything appeared to be working until I triedto modify the Navigation Toolbar.  Any changes will stick in the current browserwindow
column5: but opening another window or closing and reopening the browser resultsin the Navigation Toolbar returning to its default state.  You can even end upwith multiple location drop down boxes if you move the location drop down box toanother toolbar and open a new browser window.When I moved the profile back to the default Profiles directory and changed theprofile.ini back to a relative profile
column6: then the Navigation toolbar displayed as I set it up.  This means that the localstore.rdf file is being set correctly
column7: but for some reason it is being ignored when read in on a non-relative profile.Reproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1. Create new profile and move it out of the default location2. Modify the profiles.ini file to point to the new location and change theIsRelative line to "0"3. Open browser with that profile and attempt to modify Navigation toolbar.Actual Actual results:  Navigation toolbar reverts to default state even though localstore.rdf file waschanged.Expected Actual results:  Navigation toolbar should display as set. § 2005-09-12T15:57:08Z § 2005-09-12T19:03:16Z

column1: 1629655 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Components § 2 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§libcurl uses libpem which uses ckfw to create temporary objects whose space needs to be freed after use (rather than at token shutdown). Currently only token objects are supported and they are allocated out of a global arena owned by the slot
column2: so the objects only go away when the slot is closed. This is a problem for long running servers.The overall fix requires changes to libcurl and libpem
column3: but we also need support in nss's ckfw. This bug is only for NSS's portion of the fix. Downstream bug: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1688958§552§2 § libcurl uses libpem which uses ckfw to create temporary objects whose space needs to be freed after use (rather than at token shutdown). Currently only token objects are supported and they are allocated out of a global arena owned by the slot

column1: 1630665 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Components § 8 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§This bug is for determining a standard for passing data from the test environment to the metrics environment. I propose we use this format
column2: using jsonschema to validate that the results given agree with it:```## Full result view - it's a "partial" perfherder data blob[	{ ## Suite 1		Required("results"): <filepath>/<see below - dictionary of values with keys naming the subtest
column3: and values are replicates>
column4: Optional("shouldAlert"): True/False or dict containing a mapping of metrics to shouldAlert values
column5: Optional("alertThreshold"): 2.0
column6: Optional("name"): "browsertime"
column7: Optional("extraOptions"): []
column8: Optional("lowerIsBetter"): True/False
column9: Optional("transformer"): "SingleJsonRetriever"	}
column10: { ## Suite 2		...	}]## "results" entry as a dictionaryMeasurement name and replicates are required in this format
column11: all other fields are optional.{	"results": {		"measurement-name-1": {			Required("replicates"): [0
column15: Optional("unit"): "ms"
column16: Optional(<more-subtest-perfherder-settings>)...		}
column17: "measurement-name-2": {			...		}	}}```:tarek
column18: what do you think about this format? Essentially
column19: the test environment would be passing the metrics env some "partial" perfherder data blobs which may possibly contain settings for perfherder. If there are no special settings we use the default ones we have.With this
column20: it'll make it possible for test environments to build perfherder data blobs that is specific to them. Furthermore
column21: you'll notice that I added a `transformer` field. This will be used to determine how the results should be opened
column23: and merged. The SingleJsonRetriever will be able to handle the majority of these transforms
column24: but for cases like the ADB logcat parsing
column25: we will need to use a different one: https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/python/mozperftest/mozperftest/metrics/notebook/customtransforms/custom_single_json_retriever.py§1906§34 § This bug is for determining a standard for passing data from the test environment to the metrics environment. I propose we use this format
column26: using jsonschema to validate that the results given agree with it:```## Full result view - it's a "partial" perfherder data blob[	{ ## Suite 1		Required("results"): <filepath>/<see below - dictionary of values with keys naming the subtest
column28: Optional("shouldAlert"): True/False or dict containing a mapping of metrics to shouldAlert values
column34: { ## Suite 2		...	}]## "results" entry as a dictionaryMeasurement name and replicates are required in this format
column35: all other fields are optional.{	"results": {		"measurement-name-1": {			Required("replicates"): [0
column42: what do you think about this format? Essentially
column43: the test environment would be passing the metrics env some "partial" perfherder data blobs which may possibly contain settings for perfherder. If there are no special settings we use the default ones we have.With this
column44: it'll make it possible for test environments to build perfherder data blobs that is specific to them. Furthermore
column45: you'll notice that I added a `transformer` field. This will be used to determine how the results should be opened
column47: and merged. The SingleJsonRetriever will be able to handle the majority of these transforms
column48: but for cases like the ADB logcat parsing
column49: we will need to use a different one: https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/python/mozperftest/mozperftest/metrics/notebook/customtransforms/custom_single_json_retriever.py § 2020-04-16T16:19:05Z § 2020-05-04T20:56:18Z

It just doesn't work like it should.§171§3§: Always§9§1§:       Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.6) Gecko/20040206 Firefox/0.8I'm developing a site with ArcIMS (www.esri.com) that uses a lot of Jav Script(.js). column1: 1632687 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Components § 7 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§The Chromium-derived IPC code was
column2: as far as I can tell
column3: originally designed for Windows and assumed that channels would be named pipes
column4: managed and connected to via `std::wstring` paths.  The port to Unix
column5: however
column6: used unnamed `socketpair()` and passed them directly from process to process
column7: so it has no use for these channel IDs...  but it still computes and propagates them
column8: even though they're not used
column9: using deprecated wide-string APIs.This also indirectly causes bug 1556599
column10: because using wide strings causes glibc locale initialization which reads the environment on the I/O thread
column11: presumably racing with something on the main thread changing the environment.  Removing channel IDs isn't a proper fix for the underlying problem there — we'd need to refrain from modifying the environment while multithreaded
column12: which is a large task and outside the scope of IPC — but it will prevent this particular instance of it.§927§2 § The Chromium-derived IPC code was
column13: as far as I can tell
column14: originally designed for Windows and assumed that channels would be named pipes
column15: managed and connected to via `std::wstring` paths.  The port to Unix
column16: however
column17: used unnamed `socketpair()` and passed them directly from process to process
column18: so it has no use for these channel IDs...  but it still computes and propagates them
column20: using deprecated wide-string APIs.This also indirectly causes bug 1556599
column21: because using wide strings causes glibc locale initialization which reads the environment on the I/O thread
column22: presumably racing with something on the main thread changing the environment.  Removing channel IDs isn't a proper fix for the underlying problem there — we'd need to refrain from modifying the environment while multithreaded
column23: which is a large task and outside the scope of IPC — but it will prevent this particular instance of it. § 2020-04-23T23:48:17Z § 2020-07-23T03:25:02Z

column2: `bigIntEnabled` isn't serialized and deserialized [here](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/js/src/wasm/WasmCode.cpp#938
column4: leading to undefined behavior [here](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/js/src/jit/MCallOptimize.cpp#4003).Classifying as sec bug for now (I'm probably being paranoid)
column5: but I'd like that we take time thinking about what the consequences might be. `v128enabled` suffers from the same issue
column6: as far as i can tell.§586§3 § Thanks to dmajor who asked about this on slack.A few fields in Metadata may not be serialized or deserialized: for instance
column7: `bigIntEnabled` isn't serialized and deserialized [here](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/js/src/wasm/WasmCode.cpp#938
column9: leading to undefined behavior [here](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/js/src/jit/MCallOptimize.cpp#4003).Classifying as sec bug for now (I'm probably being paranoid)
column10: but I'd like that we take time thinking about what the consequences might be. `v128enabled` suffers from the same issue

column1: 1630336 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Client Software § 5 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§The copy_deduplicate query for `main_v4` failed this morning with a timeout after 6 hours of running. That query is the root for all desktop ETL
column2: so derived tables won't have new data until this is resolved.It appears that the problem is related to [yesterday's pipeline incident](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1630096) where we had Pub/Sub latency and we were rejecting new connections and we also had to deal with performance issues in the sinks into BigQuery.Around 16:15 UTC
column3: we see many thousands of documents that are submitted ~12 times each. Generally
column4: the submission_timestamp is the same per document_id
column5: which indicates these weren't duplicate submissions from clients but rather duplicate deliveries from PubSub.The copy_deduplicate query becomes much more expensive in the case where we have a significant number of rows with identical submission_dates as we have to window over them in order to deduplicate
column6: which requires shuffling of entire rows.§981§4 § The copy_deduplicate query for `main_v4` failed this morning with a timeout after 6 hours of running. That query is the root for all desktop ETL
column7: so derived tables won't have new data until this is resolved.It appears that the problem is related to [yesterday's pipeline incident](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1630096) where we had Pub/Sub latency and we were rejecting new connections and we also had to deal with performance issues in the sinks into BigQuery.Around 16:15 UTC
column8: we see many thousands of documents that are submitted ~12 times each. Generally
column9: the submission_timestamp is the same per document_id
column10: which indicates these weren't duplicate submissions from clients but rather duplicate deliveries from PubSub.The copy_deduplicate query becomes much more expensive in the case where we have a significant number of rows with identical submission_dates as we have to window over them in order to deduplicate
column11: which requires shuffling of entire rows. § 2020-04-15T17:25:32Z § 2020-04-16T12:47:04Z

335967 § INCOMPLETE § major § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§See details.§13§1§None§ 0§ 0§User should be able to add or modify plugin directory locations.As a comparison
column2: look at the Konqueror configuration dialog. Undocumented "gconf-style" keys are unacceptable. Usability isn't about making the interface stupid
column3: it's about making it usable. If there is no way to configure plugins
column4: then plugins are not usable.§326§2§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; Konqueror/3.5; FreeBSD) KHTML/3.5.2 (like Gecko)Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; FreeBSD i386; en-US; rv:1.8.0.2) Gecko/20060414 Firefox/1.5.0.2Preferences dialog has no way to configure plugin directories. Plugins are typically installed to a variety of locations
column5: and the same plugin can be installed to different locations on different operating systems
column6: and even different distributions of the same operating system. This makes it important to be able to configure a list of directories to search for plugins.This vital functionality is missing. In my specific case
column7: Flash7 was installed to /usr/X11R6/lib/linux-flashplugin7/libflashplayer.so
column8: but Firefox only searches for plugins in /usr/X11R6/lib/firefox/plugins. I have not been able to find any Firefox interface to add additional search paths.§846§4§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; Konqueror/3.5; FreeBSD) KHTML/3.5.2 (like Gecko)Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; FreeBSD i386; en-US; rv:1.8.0.2) Gecko/20060414 Firefox/1.5.0.2Preferences dialog has no way to configure plugin directories. Plugins are typically installed to a variety of locations
column9: and the same plugin can be installed to different locations on different operating systems
column10: and even different distributions of the same operating system. This makes it important to be able to configure a list of directories to search for plugins.This vital functionality is missing. In my specific case
column11: Flash7 was installed to /usr/X11R6/lib/linux-flashplugin7/libflashplayer.so
column12: but Firefox only searches for plugins in /usr/X11R6/lib/firefox/plugins. I have not been able to find any Firefox interface to add additional search paths.Reproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:See details.Actual Actual results:  Cannot add or modify plugin directories.Expected Actual results:  User should be able to add or modify plugin directory locations.As a comparison
column13: look at the Konqueror configuration dialog. Undocumented "gconf-style" keys are unacceptable. Usability isn't about making the interface stupid
column14: it's about making it usable. If there is no way to configure plugins
column15: then plugins are not usable. § 2006-04-30T01:37:19Z § 2010-11-15T18:48:42Z

column4: but it'll likely be a json file produced as a task artifact
column5: and notified via pulse.Since we already process the live log this way - pulse message arrives
column6: artifact is retrieved
column7: processed and data added to BigQuery - it would be good if this new artifact could be processed the same way. It would contain samples of the resources used every $time_interval (likely 1 second) so perhaps we want to aggregate that before adding to BigQuery
column8: I'm happy to take opinions on that. The questions we'd want to answer with this data are ones such as:* Are the worker instances an appropriate size
column9: or have the right concurrency set?   * Could more cores be added  * Could we use less memory  * Could we instead fit 2 tasks per worker if we increased the size slightly
column10: which would decrease our overall bill
column11: etc.* Is there a difference in resource usage after this date/time (when a commit/infra change was made

column1: 333393 § INCOMPLETE § critical § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 4 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1. From a Tektronix X term
column2: telnet to an X capable system2. export DISPLAY3. start firefox§93§3§None§ 0§ 0§It should have brought up a window.It used to work with previous versions.  A friend of mine mentioned something weird where he was on machine A
column3: ssh'd to B
column4: forwarded his display
column5: used firefox
column6: and while that session was still running
column7: went to machine B
column8: forwarded his display to machine A
column9: and it somehow sniffed out the previous session.  If this were the case
column10: it wouldn't shock me if mozilla tried to do that discovery and it failed because the X Term in question is a rather singular bit of equipment.§510§3§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060226 Firefox/1.5Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060226 Firefox/1.5From an X Terminal
column11: I use a terminal window to telnet to another system.  I export my DISPLAY variable.  I can start xclock
column12: dillo
column13: openoffice
column14: and most any other program I choose.  Firefox segfaults.  Session follows:---$ export DISPLAY="10.0.0.5:0"$ firefox/usr/lib/mozilla-firefox/mozilla-xremote-client: Error: Failed to find a running server./usr/lib/mozilla-firefox/mozilla-xremote-client: Error: Failed to find a running server.No running windows found/usr/libexec/mozilla-launcher: line 119: 29383 Segmentation fault      "$mozbin" "$@"firefox-bin exited with non-zero status (139)---§778§12§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060226 Firefox/1.5Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060226 Firefox/1.5From an X Terminal
column15: I use a terminal window to telnet to another system.  I export my DISPLAY variable.  I can start xclock
column16: dillo
column17: openoffice
column18: and most any other program I choose.  Firefox segfaults.  Session follows:---$ export DISPLAY="10.0.0.5:0"$ firefox/usr/lib/mozilla-firefox/mozilla-xremote-client: Error: Failed to find a running server./usr/lib/mozilla-firefox/mozilla-xremote-client: Error: Failed to find a running server.No running windows found/usr/libexec/mozilla-launcher: line 119: 29383 Segmentation fault      "$mozbin" "$@"firefox-bin exited with non-zero status (139)---Reproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1. From a Tektronix X term
column19: telnet to an X capable system2. export DISPLAY3. start firefoxActual Actual results:  $ export DISPLAY="10.0.0.5:0"$ firefox/usr/lib/mozilla-firefox/mozilla-xremote-client: Error: Failed to find a running server./usr/lib/mozilla-firefox/mozilla-xremote-client: Error: Failed to find a running server.No running windows found/usr/libexec/mozilla-launcher: line 119: 29383 Segmentation fault      "$mozbin" "$@"firefox-bin exited with non-zero status (139)Expected Actual results:  It should have brought up a window.It used to work with previous versions.  A friend of mine mentioned something weird where he was on machine A
column23: and while that session was still running
column25: forwarded his display to machine A
column26: and it somehow sniffed out the previous session.  If this were the case
column27: it wouldn't shock me if mozilla tried to do that discovery and it failed because the X Term in question is a rather singular bit of equipment. § 2006-04-10T02:34:11Z § 2011-02-02T05:58:27Z

column1: 1636245 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Other § 36 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§As part of the current cost reduction efforts
column2: we're trying to reduce the number of cloud providers we support
column3: specifically by exiting packet.net. Over in bug 1632599
column4: we're trying to move Mozilla CI workloads out of packet.net and into AWS now that Amazon supports bare metal instance types. There is currently a [single
column5: statically-provisioned ARM machine](https://firefox-ci-tc.services.mozilla.com/provisioners/localprovisioner/worker-types/nss-aarch64) that was setup for NSS testing that is the last machine we have running in packet.net.Amazon has a [variety of ARM options now](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/a1/). We'd like to transition NSS to AWS from packet.net.Here are the specs for the current machine in packet.net:* PROC: 2 x Cavium ThunderX CN8890 @2GHz* RAM: 128GB* DISK: 1 x 340GB SSD* NIC: 2 x 10Gbps Bonded PortsI'd would humbly suggest that this is over-provisioned for running a single CI worker. I think an a1.large instance in AWS would be sufficient for the new pool. I also think that we can get away with a very small pool here
column6: capping the max # of instances at 5 (or less) given that check-ins are infrequent and a single worker is keeping up just fine right now.Note: I've cc-ed some Taskcluster folks here because I'm unsure about the vintage of docker-worker that's running on ARM in packet.net. We may need to engage with releng to get something running on ARM in AWS.See also bug 1594891 where releng inherited many of the other NSS worker pools.§1504§10 § As part of the current cost reduction efforts
column7: we're trying to reduce the number of cloud providers we support
column8: specifically by exiting packet.net. Over in bug 1632599
column9: we're trying to move Mozilla CI workloads out of packet.net and into AWS now that Amazon supports bare metal instance types. There is currently a [single
column10: statically-provisioned ARM machine](https://firefox-ci-tc.services.mozilla.com/provisioners/localprovisioner/worker-types/nss-aarch64) that was setup for NSS testing that is the last machine we have running in packet.net.Amazon has a [variety of ARM options now](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/a1/). We'd like to transition NSS to AWS from packet.net.Here are the specs for the current machine in packet.net:* PROC: 2 x Cavium ThunderX CN8890 @2GHz* RAM: 128GB* DISK: 1 x 340GB SSD* NIC: 2 x 10Gbps Bonded PortsI'd would humbly suggest that this is over-provisioned for running a single CI worker. I think an a1.large instance in AWS would be sufficient for the new pool. I also think that we can get away with a very small pool here
column11: capping the max # of instances at 5 (or less) given that check-ins are infrequent and a single worker is keeping up just fine right now.Note: I've cc-ed some Taskcluster folks here because I'm unsure about the vintage of docker-worker that's running on ARM in packet.net. We may need to engage with releng to get something running on ARM in AWS.See also bug 1594891 where releng inherited many of the other NSS worker pools. § 2020-05-07T19:11:53Z § 2020-11-05T17:16:31Z

column2: then that could be combined with the `widget.disable-native-theme-for-content` pref to yield a browser where:1. Content processes shouldn't be able to communicate directly with the X server2. WebGL and Flash are broken3. A lot of automated tests are broken because of the widget theme changeSo that configuration isn't shippable yet
column3: but it could be useful for use cases that weren't going to use WebGL or Flash anyway
column4: and for experimenting to see if anything else is broken that we don't know about.§735§5 § If we had a pref to set `MOZ_HEADLESS` for content processes (as described in bug 1129492 comment #21) and turn off the file broker rules that allow brokered connections to the X server (needed for some GL interposition layers)

column1: 1632605 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Components § 3 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§It looks like we can access update error data now [via BiqQuery](https://sql.telemetry.mozilla.org/queries/70340/source#177141) in ways that we could not previously when the [update orphaning dash](https://telemetry.mozilla.org/update-orphaning/) was created.To start
column2: let's make a simple dash that shows: The distribution of up to date/out of date (concern)/out of date (possible concern) over time
column3: split out by channels.Assuming that's do-able
column4: I'll file follow ups to add for specific errors.Logic by channel will be as follows:* Release - up to date = major versions going back 2 behind release.* Beta & Dev Edition - up to date = major versions matching release.* Nightly - up to date = running a current weekly release.§733§7 § It looks like we can access update error data now [via BiqQuery](https://sql.telemetry.mozilla.org/queries/70340/source#177141) in ways that we could not previously when the [update orphaning dash](https://telemetry.mozilla.org/update-orphaning/) was created.To start
column5: let's make a simple dash that shows: The distribution of up to date/out of date (concern)/out of date (possible concern) over time
column6: split out by channels.Assuming that's do-able
column7: I'll file follow ups to add for specific errors.Logic by channel will be as follows:* Release - up to date = major versions going back 2 behind release.* Beta & Dev Edition - up to date = major versions matching release.* Nightly - up to date = running a current weekly release. § 2020-04-23T19:03:19Z § 2020-06-24T16:14:22Z

column1: 1643211 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Other § 7 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§A BCJ filter works by converting relative offsets into absolute positions in code
column2: to increase redundancy by representing all references to a position by the same bytes. This assumes that the files are executables and performs a simple disassembly to locate the relative offsets. This disassembly is optimized for speed and doesn't have to be completely accurate
column3: but inaccurately-identified targets will reduce compressibility. Also
column4: some relative offsets are likely to be fairly common (e.g. short-distance branches)
column5: while the positions they refer to are individually referenced more rarely. Generally these issues are more than offset by the improvement in commonly-referenced code.Our update .mars use this on each file in the update
column6: whether it is a wholly new file or a BSDiff patch. In the case of a patch this analysis is not as valuable because the patch contains pieces of new code at arbitrary positions
column7: so relative offsets will not translate reliably to the same absolute position.The upshot is that using BCJ increases patch size. Here are the effects on recent partial updates of disabling BCJ:update | arch | BCJ | no BCJ | decrease---| --- | --- | --- | ---76.0-77.0 | win32 | 12
column28: but it is simple to fix.§1504§10 § A BCJ filter works by converting relative offsets into absolute positions in code
column29: to increase redundancy by representing all references to a position by the same bytes. This assumes that the files are executables and performs a simple disassembly to locate the relative offsets. This disassembly is optimized for speed and doesn't have to be completely accurate
column30: but inaccurately-identified targets will reduce compressibility. Also
column31: some relative offsets are likely to be fairly common (e.g. short-distance branches)
column32: while the positions they refer to are individually referenced more rarely. Generally these issues are more than offset by the improvement in commonly-referenced code.Our update .mars use this on each file in the update
column33: whether it is a wholly new file or a BSDiff patch. In the case of a patch this analysis is not as valuable because the patch contains pieces of new code at arbitrary positions
column34: so relative offsets will not translate reliably to the same absolute position.The upshot is that using BCJ increases patch size. Here are the effects on recent partial updates of disabling BCJ:update | arch | BCJ | no BCJ | decrease---| --- | --- | --- | ---76.0-77.0 | win32 | 12

244388 § INVALID § trivial § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1. Open http://www.the-noodle.com/links.htm2. Click Science on the list on the left side§90§2§None§ 0§ 0§There should be no shift in the columns.I have replicated this on two PC's running Firefox 0.8
column2: one in Windows2000 Pro
column3: the other in WindowsXP.  The font & colors settings are the default:Fonts for: WesternProportional: Serif
column4: Size: 16Serif: Times New RomanSans Serif: ArialMonospace: Courier New
column5: Size: 13Display Resolution: 96dpiMinimum Font Size: noneThe only other box that is checked is for underline links (neither Always useboxes are checked).I had a friend try to replicate the problem on Firefox 0.7
column6: but he could not.The style sheet is avalable at http://the-noodle.com/includes/noodle_basic.css§618§14§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.6) Gecko/20040206 Firefox/0.8Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.6) Gecko/20040206 Firefox/0.8On this URL
column7: if you select "Science" on the left-hand list of categories
column8: itbrings up an entry on the right that contains a string that contains a period(.)
column9: which causes the table widths to shift slightly.  If you take out theperiod
column10: the columns don't shift.  If you put in longer text (replace the periodwith the word "dot"
column11: for instance)
column12: the columns don't shift.  If the width ofthe text to the left of the period is less than a specific amount
column13: the columnsdon't shift (even if the text to the right of the period increases by the sameamount or more).  This is very strange and hard to believe
column14: but I will give thesteps I took to test this.1) The page structure:This part of the page contains a table with two <td>'s.  The left <td> containsan <h1>
column15: an <h2>
column16:
a

with some text
column17: and a <ul> with several <li>'s.  Theright <td> contains several <dl>'s
column18: each with a <dt> and one or more <dd>'s. Each <dd> contains an anchor surrounding one or more words of text.  All of the<dl>'s on the right have style="display: none;" set
column19: to keep them from beingdisplayed.  Each <li> on the left contains an anchor which invokes a JavaScriptthat sets the style for each <dl> to display:none
column20: and then removes that stylefrom the appropriate dl
column21: causing it to be displayed.  The layout of the columnsis controlled using CSS
column22: and all of the <dl>'s use the same class to control howthey are displayed.  All of this works as expected.2)The unexpected behavior:Clicking on each of the anchors on the left causes the appropriate <dl> todisplay on the right
column24: except for one of them -"Science".  When Science is selected
column25: the columns shift so that the left side isslightly narrower
column26:
causing the content of the

on the left side to line-breakdifferently.3)The cause:I traced the cause of the problem to the text "Space.com" in an in the

under the
for science on the right side. I did numerous tests and foundthat if I removed the period
column27: or shortened the amount of text to the left of theperiod
column28: the unexpected shift did not occur.  3) Tests:3a)Changing the text inside the <a>:"Spacedotcom" or "Spaceisreallygreat" does not produce the shift
column29: so it is notthe width of the text overall that causes the shift.  "Spac.com" does not produce the shift
column30: so reducing the amount of text to theleft of the period prevents the problem from occurring."Spac.com web site" does not produce the shift
column32: so the amount of text on the right side has no effect."Spjce.com web site" does not produce the shift
column33: so it is not the number ofcharacters to the left of the period that causes the shift
column34: but rather the widthof that text."iiiii.com" does not produce the shift
column36: confirming that itis the width of the text to the left of the period that causes the shift.Replacing "." with . has no effect.  The behavior is the same in the abovetests.Removing the anchor prevents the shift from occurring.  Changing the content of the anchor does not have any effect.Moving the <dd> and its content into a different <dl> does not have any effecton the behavior (they are all controlled by the same class
column37: so I expected therenot to be a difference).I removed all <dl>'s on the right side
column39: so that all I had onthe right side is one <dl> with one <dd> inside
column40: with one <a> inside containingthe string "Space.com" and all the variations above.  Same behavior.§3676§56§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.6) Gecko/20040206 Firefox/0.8Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.6) Gecko/20040206 Firefox/0.8On this URL
column41: if you select "Science" on the left-hand list of categories
column42: itbrings up an entry on the right that contains a string that contains a period(.)
column43: which causes the table widths to shift slightly.  If you take out theperiod
column44: the columns don't shift.  If you put in longer text (replace the periodwith the word "dot"
column46: the columns don't shift.  If the width ofthe text to the left of the period is less than a specific amount
column47: the columnsdon't shift (even if the text to the right of the period increases by the sameamount or more).  This is very strange and hard to believe
column48: but I will give thesteps I took to test this.1) The page structure:This part of the page contains a table with two <td>'s.  The left <td> containsan <h1>
column51: and a <ul> with several <li>'s.  Theright <td> contains several <dl>'s
column52: each with a <dt> and one or more <dd>'s. Each <dd> contains an anchor surrounding one or more words of text.  All of the<dl>'s on the right have style="display: none;" set
column53: to keep them from beingdisplayed.  Each <li> on the left contains an anchor which invokes a JavaScriptthat sets the style for each <dl> to display:none
column54: and then removes that stylefrom the appropriate dl
column55: causing it to be displayed.  The layout of the columnsis controlled using CSS
column56: and all of the <dl>'s use the same class to control howthey are displayed.  All of this works as expected.2)The unexpected behavior:Clicking on each of the anchors on the left causes the appropriate <dl> todisplay on the right
column58: except for one of them -"Science".  When Science is selected
column59: the columns shift so that the left side isslightly narrower
column60:
causing the content of the

on the left side to line-breakdifferently.3)The cause:I traced the cause of the problem to the text "Space.com" in an in the

under the
for science on the right side. I did numerous tests and foundthat if I removed the period
column61: or shortened the amount of text to the left of theperiod
column62: the unexpected shift did not occur.  3) Tests:3a)Changing the text inside the <a>:"Spacedotcom" or "Spaceisreallygreat" does not produce the shift
column63: so it is notthe width of the text overall that causes the shift.  "Spac.com" does not produce the shift
column64: so reducing the amount of text to theleft of the period prevents the problem from occurring."Spac.com web site" does not produce the shift
column66: so the amount of text on the right side has no effect."Spjce.com web site" does not produce the shift
column67: so it is not the number ofcharacters to the left of the period that causes the shift
column68: but rather the widthof that text."iiiii.com" does not produce the shift
column70: confirming that itis the width of the text to the left of the period that causes the shift.Replacing "." with . has no effect.  The behavior is the same in the abovetests.Removing the anchor prevents the shift from occurring.  Changing the content of the anchor does not have any effect.Moving the <dd> and its content into a different <dl> does not have any effecton the behavior (they are all controlled by the same class
column71: so I expected therenot to be a difference).I removed all <dl>'s on the right side
column73: so that all I had onthe right side is one <dl> with one <dd> inside
column74: with one <a> inside containingthe string "Space.com" and all the variations above.  Same behavior.Reproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1. Open http://www.the-noodle.com/links.htm2. Click Science on the list on the left sideActual Actual results:  Columns shift to the left
column75: causing the left column to be narrower
column76:
causing thecontent of the

to line-break differently. Click any of the other links
column77: andthe columns shift back.Expected Actual results:  There should be no shift in the columns.I have replicated this on two PC's running Firefox 0.8
column79: the other in WindowsXP.  The font & colors settings are the default:Fonts for: WesternProportional: Serif
column80: Size: 16Serif: Times New RomanSans Serif: ArialMonospace: Courier New
column81: Size: 13Display Resolution: 96dpiMinimum Font Size: noneThe only other box that is checked is for underline links (neither Always useboxes are checked).I had a friend try to replicate the problem on Firefox 0.7

column1: 1643863 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 8 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§MacOS l10n repacks failing on 78.0beta1I made some changes in Bug 1619767 to mail/config/mozconfigs/l10n-common in anticipation of automated merge day activities happening. column2: the `browsertime` specific code needs to be moved out of the core perfdocs code (which is where it is now [2]) and into the Raptor framework gatherer [3].To do this
column3: we need to implement a `build_test_descriptions` method in the framework gatherers that takes as arguments a test name and a description and returns a document section/chunk for that test.The method should look something like:```def build_test_description(test_name
column4: test_description=None):    # Build test description
column5: or modify the given description into a document chunk    return <DOCUMENT-CHUNK>```For example
column6: if we call it like: `build_test_description("amazon"
column7: "Browsertime amazon desktop test")`Then
column8: it would return:```>> ret = build_test_description("amazon"
column9: "Browsertime amazon desktop test.")>> retBrowsertime amazon^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^Browsertime amazon desktop test.```Note that the `_append_rst_section` function [1] will also need to be moved into the framework gatherer along with the browsertime specific code below it [2].[1]: https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/tools/lint/perfdocs/generator.py#62-76[2]: https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/tools/lint/perfdocs/generator.py#98-112[3]: https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/tools/lint/perfdocs/framework_gatherers.py#69§1424§22 § This bug is for implementing what was discussed here: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1633890#c5Specifically

column1: 1645334 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Components § 4 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§The `WatcherActor`  does have specific code to handle watching resources in parent process ([devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#188-200](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/0e09b9191c02097034e46b193930f91c45b7885d/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#188-200))
column2: by retrieving the `browsingContextID` from the `browser` option passed when instantiating it ([devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#35
column3: 57-59](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/0e09b9191c02097034e46b193930f91c45b7885d/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#35
column4: 57-59)).Unfortunately
column5: in [devtools/server/actors/descriptors/process.js#145](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/0e09b9191c02097034e46b193930f91c45b7885d/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/process.js#145)
column6: we're creating the `WatcherActor` for the `ProcessDescriptorActor` without the `browser` option
column7: which means the watcherActor won't be able to retrieve the targetActor.As a result
column8: we won't watch resources in parent processes (you can see that by flipping the `[Resources.TYPES.CONSOLE_MESSAGE]` trait
column9: opening the browser toolbox and evaluating `console.log("bloup")`; the `bloup` message won't appear).§1223§3 § The `WatcherActor`  does have specific code to handle watching resources in parent process ([devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#188-200](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/0e09b9191c02097034e46b193930f91c45b7885d/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#188-200))
column10: by retrieving the `browsingContextID` from the `browser` option passed when instantiating it ([devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#35
column11: 57-59](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/0e09b9191c02097034e46b193930f91c45b7885d/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#35
column12: 57-59)).Unfortunately
column13: in [devtools/server/actors/descriptors/process.js#145](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/0e09b9191c02097034e46b193930f91c45b7885d/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/process.js#145)
column14: we're creating the `WatcherActor` for the `ProcessDescriptorActor` without the `browser` option
column15: which means the watcherActor won't be able to retrieve the targetActor.As a result
column16: we won't watch resources in parent processes (you can see that by flipping the `[Resources.TYPES.CONSOLE_MESSAGE]` trait
column17: opening the browser toolbox and evaluating `console.log("bloup")`; the `bloup` message won't appear). § 2020-06-12T09:59:16Z § 2020-06-17T03:46:02Z

1637292 § WONTFIX § -- § task § RESOLVED § Client Software § 2 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§We saw yesterday that we are getting some pings with document types like the following:```health'health]]>><health"event]]>><```We were expecting these to fail with `SchemaNotFoundException` but these are making it further in the pipeline and instead failing as `DuplicateIdException`.§293§8 § We saw yesterday that we are getting some pings with document types like the following:```health'health]]>><health"event]]>><```We were expecting these to fail with `SchemaNotFoundException` but these are making it further in the pipeline and instead failing as `DuplicateIdException`. § 2020-05-12T15:38:11Z § 2020-05-12T15:45:17Z

column1: 1637423 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Developer Infrastructure § 4 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§I relaxed the login requirements in bug 1620160 since taskcluster credentials are separate and required to do any sort of PUT/POST request to taskcluster. Login to Treeherder is only really needed for writing to Treeherder's database (I think only classifications or adding notes by sheriffs).However
column2: I discovered a bug during our UX research interviews where taskcluster credentials will be checked before retriggering a job (regardless of whether the user is logged in or not). If they don't exist or have expired
column3: they should be retrieved and then the action performed. Currently
column4: they are retrieved but then an error is being thrown so users have to click again to actually retrigger and it's confusing.Users are also expecting to be logged in when that happens
column5: not just have taskcluster credentials retrieved (if necessary) and the action performed.§859§3 § I relaxed the login requirements in bug 1620160 since taskcluster credentials are separate and required to do any sort of PUT/POST request to taskcluster. Login to Treeherder is only really needed for writing to Treeherder's database (I think only classifications or adding notes by sheriffs).However
column6: I discovered a bug during our UX research interviews where taskcluster credentials will be checked before retriggering a job (regardless of whether the user is logged in or not). If they don't exist or have expired
column7: they should be retrieved and then the action performed. Currently
column8: they are retrieved but then an error is being thrown so users have to click again to actually retrigger and it's confusing.Users are also expecting to be logged in when that happens
column9: not just have taskcluster credentials retrieved (if necessary) and the action performed. § 2020-05-12T21:13:06Z § 2020-05-16T00:16:04Z

column2: `ResourceWatcher.watch` is expected to call the `onAvailable` callback for resources which already exists. i.e. for resources that were created *before* the call to `watch()`.But:1) There is no way to only listen for "future" resources. i.e. only the one which are created *after* the call to `watch()`. And bug 1626494 highlighted a case where that would be useful.2) Bug 1625961 highlighted that `watch` was inconsistant
column3: and while the first call would notify about past and future resources
column4: all other calls after the first one would only notify about the future ones. We are currently relying on this inconsistancy in order to only retrieve future resources for DOCUMENT_EVENTS resource. Such flag would help addressing this inconsistancy by being explicit about it. The current codebase uses a whitelist
column5: but that is imperfect as the inconsistancy is still here for DOCUMENT_EVENTS.I imagine we could probably first introduce a dictionnary argument in `ResourceWatcher.watch` (bug 1637561)
column6: then
column7: here we would expose new optional boolean: `watchOnlyFutureResources`
column8: or `onlyFuture`
column9: ... (or any naming that makes sense).Then
column10: regarding how to implement this attribute
column11: we might try to convey this boolean down to the legacy listeners
column12: so that we avoid fetching "cached"/"past" resources.For example
column13: we could avoid executing [these lines](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/0688ffdef223dac527c2fcdb25560118c4e4df51/devtools/shared/resources/legacy-listeners/console-messages.js#36-40).Later on in bug 1626647
column14: we may pass this flag to the WatcherActor so that it knows if it should emit past resources or not.Note that depending on how we implement that
column15: we may have inconsistancy depending on the call order of `watch({ onlyFuture: false })` versus `watch({ onlyFuture: true })`Also
column16: I think that this behavior "only listen for future resources" is most likely going to be rare and should be considered as an edge case.We may add various restriction to it
column17: like:* only accept listening for future resource *after* a call to watch has been made listening for everything?* only accept listening for only future for a few special resources?Given this
column18: we may expose this feature through an API other than `watch`.We could for example expose:* `onNextResource(resourceType)` returning a promise
column21: but with an optional callback to filter out the resource
column22: in order to match a precise one.* or some other naming or interface that makes sense!This function could throw if we weren't already watching for this resource type. Or automagically start calling watch
column23: but be careful of inconsistancy of call order between `watch` and `onNextResource`.§2797§19 § Currently

And bug 1626494 highlighted a case where that would be useful.2) Bug 1625961 highlighted that `watch` was inconsistant
