column1: 331449 § INVALID § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 5 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1.Open a page where you have a link to a PDF document2.Use the PDFs normally3. Close the documentOpen the the process monitor in Windows. You will find AcroRd32.exe running.Exit Firefox. AcroRd32 is still running§217§5§None§ 0§ 0§The AcroRd32.exe should be stopped at least when Firefox is closedIt looks like that eventually that we have some kind of conflicts which may hang Firefox - trying over and over again to open an already busy process.I have seen many bugs with similar complaints
column2: which just might be resolved by addressing this bug.I am using my own build from the trunk
column3: Visual C++ 2005 Express..mozconfig:. $topsrcdir/browser/config/mozconfigac_add_options --enable-application=browserac_add_options --enable-optimize="-O2 -GA"ac_add_options --enable-cryptoac_add_options --disable-testsac_add_options --disable-debugac_add_options --disable-accessibilityac_add_options --disable-activexac_add_options --disable-activex-scriptingac_add_options --disable-xpconnect-idispatchac_add_options --enable-staticac_add_options --disable-sharedac_add_options --disable-placesac_add_options --enable-svgac_add_options --enable-canvasac_add_options --enable-default-toolkit=cairo-windows§981§21§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a1) Gecko/20060323 Firefox/1.6a1Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a1) Gecko/20060323 Firefox/1.6a1Once a pdf document has been opened within the browser the AcroRd32.exe process is not killed even after exiting Firefox.If you continue and open the browser again and open again pdf:s
column4: it happens eventually that everything becomes unresponsive
column5: and you have to exit Firefox.It looks like the only way out is to manually kill the AcroRd32.exe process with all its child processes.Normally you would expect the AcroRd32.exe process to be killed when it is no longer needed by Firefox
column6: at least it must never run after exiting Firefox.§737§6§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a1) Gecko/20060323 Firefox/1.6a1Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a1) Gecko/20060323 Firefox/1.6a1Once a pdf document has been opened within the browser the AcroRd32.exe process is not killed even after exiting Firefox.If you continue and open the browser again and open again pdf:s
column7: it happens eventually that everything becomes unresponsive
column8: and you have to exit Firefox.It looks like the only way out is to manually kill the AcroRd32.exe process with all its child processes.Normally you would expect the AcroRd32.exe process to be killed when it is no longer needed by Firefox
column9: at least it must never run after exiting Firefox.Reproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1.Open a page where you have a link to a PDF document2.Use the PDFs normally3. Close the documentOpen the the process monitor in Windows. You will find AcroRd32.exe running.Exit Firefox. AcroRd32 is still runningActual Actual results:  AcroRd32.exe is running even after exiting FirefoxExpected Actual results:  The AcroRd32.exe should be stopped at least when Firefox is closedIt looks like that eventually that we have some kind of conflicts which may hang Firefox - trying over and over again to open an already busy process.I have seen many bugs with similar complaints
column10: which just might be resolved by addressing this bug.I am using my own build from the trunk

1644349 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Components § 8 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Currently we use a Map to translate the inner window id to the browsing context id of the frame where the network activity takes place:https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/35b97af64a55d1d30caa4d6e9fabc1a7fbabc509/remote/observers/NetworkObserver.jsm#57As I just noticed this map is not necessary. Instead we can use the [httpChannel.loadInfo.frameBrowsingContextID](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/35b97af64a55d1d30caa4d6e9fabc1a7fbabc509/netwerk/base/nsILoadInfo.idl#743) to identify the frame id for the sub requests.§537§3 § Currently we use a Map to translate the inner window id to the browsing context id of the frame where the network activity takes place:https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/35b97af64a55d1d30caa4d6e9fabc1a7fbabc509/remote/observers/NetworkObserver.jsm#57As I just noticed this map is not necessary. Instead we can use the [httpChannel.loadInfo.frameBrowsingContextID](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/35b97af64a55d1d30caa4d6e9fabc1a7fbabc509/netwerk/base/nsILoadInfo.idl#743) to identify the frame id for the sub requests. § 2020-06-09T08:07:22Z § 2021-04-12T22:28:42Z

column2: debug or other purposes I would like to have gotten the a similar notification but with the choice:- No noting- Install over existing versionThis dialog should not be an error
column3: because it is not an error.Justification is that I have been doing development on a search tool that I maintain and get these errors
column4: see first screenshot. In this case the content is different and is not an error as such. Other users that I ask to test or install my new version also get this error. See second screenshot. In this case it is also not an error. People think my search tool is broken or that they cannot install/upgrade (even though they might be already at the latest version
column5: but that is not the user experience they have). column6: debug or other purposes I would like to have gotten the a similar notification but with the choice:- No noting- Install over existing versionThis dialog should not be an error
column7: because it is not an error.Justification is that I have been doing development on a search tool that I maintain and get these errors

column4: I'm not even sure whether this is a bug or a feature.  All I know is it's screwing up my presentations.I'm using an IFRAME element in an S5 slide show.  You've probably heard of S5
column5: but just to recap
column6: it's a nifty JavaScript that lets you treat an HTML document as a slide show (like a PowerPoint presentation).[1]  I love using IFRAME with this
column7: because it lets me put a live web page right in one of my slides.  When I reach the slide
column8: I can demonstrate exactly what I'm talking about
column9: click links
column10: whatever
column11: and then continue.Unfortunately
column12: as of FireFox 2.0.0.1 and higher
column13: this technique no longer works.  The symptoms are really weird.  When I get to the slide containing the IFRAME
column14: the page has not loaded.  The screen space is reserved
column15: but it just shows the underlying background.  I KNOW that the source code for the linked page was downloaded and rendered: I've got the HTML Validator extension
column16: [2] and it checks the source code for the IFRAME as well as the slide show.The IFRAME works in IE 6 and in Safari.  I downloaded multiple versions of Firefox
column17: and did some testing using the URL I gave above):Firefox 1.5.0.11: IFRAME worksFirefox 2.0.0.0: IFRAME worksFirefox 2.0.0.1: IFRAME does not workFirefox 2.0.0.2: IFRAME does not workFirefox 2.0.0.3: IFRAME does not workIt took ages to do all that testing
column18: since I completely uninstalled Firefox and wiped my profile for each version (thank goodness for sandbox machines).If I disable JavaScript
column19: then the IFRAME works perfectly in all versions.  Unfortunately
column20: disabling JavaScript also destroys its usefulness
column21: because in the absence of JavaScript the file is not a slide show.  It's just a rather boring-looking HTML page.Furthermore
column22: there's some really weird behavior regarding which slide the IFRAME is in.  Sometimes
column23: if it's in a slide which is even partially visible on the screen during the initial loading sequence
column25: then the IFRAME loads fine
column26: and its contents remain visible.  Other times
column28: but then when I get to the slide with the IFRAME
column29: its contents are gone.  This sometimes-there-sometimes-not behavior is really bizarre.  I haven't been able to pin down what's causing it exactly; I can tell you that the times it worked properly (when the IFRAME was initially visible) all occurred in 2.0.0.3.  You can see a test case with an IFRAME that's close to the top here:http://instructors.cwrl.utexas.edu/~martin/Audit/show/test.htmlAs I said at the beginning
column30: I'm not sure whether this is a bug or a feature.It might be a bug because it's really weird that the IFRAME would download the source code but not render it
column31: and because it happens so erratically.It might be a feature because phishers sometimes try to use hidden IFRAMEs in evil ways.  Because the S5 scripts depend on altering the visibility of the slide elements
column32: the IFRAMEs aren't always visible.  So Mozilla may be suppressing the output of the IFRAME on the theory that it might have been part of a phishing scheme.Could someone please tell me whether this is a bug or a feature?  If it's a bug
column34: but also obscure.  If it's a feature
column35: then it's having some unintended consequences.  And either way
column36: I'd like a work-around if anybody can think of one.  I have a presentation coming up on Wednesday
column37: and I need my IFRAMEs.  Links won't do
column38: because the whole point of the presentation is to demonstrate the use of IFRAME in a slide show!I could use Internet Exploder
column39: but I think I'd rather slit my wrists.  I could use Safari
column40: and that's actually an option since the classroom where I'm presenting is equipped with both Mac and PC.  Or

They seem quite eager to try and process the MARPLE set of examples. We agreed on certain attributes which can be used to describe single striae
column53: once we have distilled those   attributes from the raw database files (estimated time: end of July)
column54: the   Warsawers will run them through their machine inference mills. They also have   established links with a high-tech company in Germany
column55: who may become an   industrial partner in the new project. I am sorry to say that the computer   department of the Bydgoszcz police command were rather a disappointment in   that role; while we provided them with algorithms and structures
column56: they never   got down to implementing them as fully usable systems. I can hardly blame   them
column57: given that their staff was decimated during Poland's recent reform of   territorial administration
column58: which nearly stripped Bydgoszcz of its status as   regional capital. Still
column59: I have to look for a more stable and truly   _industrial_ partner in the future
column60: and the German company may be a viable   option. For our project to succeed under the 5th Framework Programme
column61: we will   need the involvement of at least 5 or six entities (institutions
column63: and companies) from at least 3 countries. The Netherlands
column64: Poland and Germany   make 3 countries; your lab
column66: ICS PAS and their German friends...   that's 4 entities; we need a few more partners. I am thinking about the French   universities of Lille and Valenciennes

column123: who may become an   industrial partner in the new project. I am sorry to say that the computer   department of the Bydgoszcz police command were rather a disappointment in   that role; while we provided them with algorithms and structures
column124: they never   got down to implementing them as fully usable systems. I can hardly blame   them
column125: given that their staff was decimated during Poland's recent reform of   territorial administration

column30: which would watch all:* new worker being created and call [WatcherActor.notifyTargetCreated](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/21f2b48e01f2e14a94e8d39a665b56fcc08ecbdb/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#138)* workers that have been destroyed and call [WatcherActor.notifyTargetDestroyed](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/21f2b48e01f2e14a94e8d39a665b56fcc08ecbdb/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/watcher.js#142-147)We might have to hook up into [WatcherRegistry](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/server/actors/descriptors/watcher/WatcherRegistry.jsm) in order to register/unregister this "worker watching" code. Similarly to how we register/unregister the DevToolsFrame JSWindow Actor. (Or see my other approach for content process target
column31: `maybeRegisterMessageListeners` in [this patch](https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D65529?vs=on&id=290273#toc))The goal here would be to start by only supporting Tab Target. So only when `WatcherActor._browser`/`WatcherActor.browsingContextID` are set. And so only when we focus on just one BrowsingContext. Supporting the browser toolbox means having to inspect all the processes
column33: we can focus on just one process at a time. (We may support navigation to another process in a followup)Compared to the current implementation
column34: using legacy listeners and `TabTarget.listWorkers`
column36: we should avoid involving TabTarget/BrowsingContextTargetActor. We might have to introduce a new JS Window Actor
column37: or reuse DevToolsFrame JS Window Actor (if relevant).You might want to contribute to the existing TargetList test specific to Worker targets:https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/21f2b48e01f2e14a94e8d39a665b56fcc08ecbdb/devtools/shared/resources/tests/browser_target_list_workers.js#190-234In order to support more usecases:* destruction* workers created after the call to watchTargets* may be have two distinct test files? One for BrowserToolbox codepath and another one for Tabs?Last but not list
column38: a quick note about the existing codebase.The code watching for new workers and workers being destroyed should be inspired from [WorkerTargetActorList](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/server/actors/worker/worker-target-actor-list.js).* `matchWorkerDebugger` should be tweaked to check WatcherActor's BrowsingContextID instead of window.* WorkerPauser should be kept until we address bug 1573327WorkerPauser is actually including a very important bit that is a bit convoluted and not very well known.[Right here](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/21f2b48e01f2e14a94e8d39a665b56fcc08ecbdb/devtools/server/actors/worker/worker-target-actor-list.js#87-89)

column46: this is done by WorkerPauser2) Completely independently of that
column49: via listWorkers and WorkerTargetActorList3) We use WorkerConnector to create the WorkerTargetActor from the Worker thread4) The frontend receive the worker target5) The frontend attach the ThreadActor6) [Some magic code](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/server/startup/worker.js#105) from the worker thread notify the main thread that the Thread Actor is attached7) [Some other magic code](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/21f2b48e01f2e14a94e8d39a665b56fcc08ecbdb/devtools/server/connectors/worker-connector.js#37-41) in the main thread receive this message and resume the workerAll this "magic" (complexity) relates to bug 1573327 as it will allow to pass the breakpoint to the Watcher Actor
column50: and stop having to freeze the worker untils ThreadActor.attach is called. Today

column1: 1633943 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Components § 7 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§`webext_storage::Store::close` landed in https://github.com/mozilla/application-services/pull/3042
column2: let's upgrade our vendored a-s version to support that.One thing I've been thinking about over the last couple of days is how to handle errors from `close`/`teardown`. Rusqlite connections have a [`Drop` implementation](https://github.com/rusqlite/rusqlite/blob/65ef2224b6c36ee7d298331ee45349844a8bed80/src/inner_connection.rs#L298-L311) that tries to automatically close the connection
column3: and panic if that fails. On Desktop
column4: this will cause a crash
column5: since we compile with [`panic = "abort"`](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/2bfe3415fb3a2fba9b1c694bc0b376365e086927/Cargo.toml#59
column6: 65).Even if we don't crash
column7: though
column8: dropping the last reference to a Rust `StorageSyncArea` XPCOM class without calling `teardown` will drop its `LazyStore`
column9: which drops its `webext_storage::Store`
column10: which drops its `rusqlite::Connection`
column11: which drops its `InnerConnection`...which closes the connection on the main thread.While this isn't ideal
column12: I think it's OK as a last resort—especially since mozStorage does [something similar](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/2bfe3415fb3a2fba9b1c694bc0b376365e086927/storage/mozStorageConnection.cpp#541-543). Consumers should always call `teardown` explicitly
column13: and not rely on automatic cleanup by the last reference falling out of scope. As Mark points out in [this comment](https://github.com/mozilla/application-services/pull/3042#discussion_r416404414)
column14: "the last reference falling out of scope" is a hazy concept
column15: because XPCOM objects in JS are GCed—meaning XPConnect will release the object sometime later
column16: not immediately.It's also an edge case within an edge case: 1) we'll only synchronously close the connection on the main thread if a) someone is misusing a `StorageSyncArea`
column17: which shouldn't happen given that we have our `StorageSyncService` always holding one strong reference
column18: and that's what Sync and `ExtensionStorageSync.jsm` go through
column19: or b) dispatching the `teardown` runnable fails
column20: which should only happen at shutdown
column22: anyway...and 2) we'll only crash if `close` itself fails
column23: which it shouldn't given that we serialize all operations on the task queue
column24: and `rusqlite::Connection::close` already cleans up cached statements before trying to close the connection.That's a really
column25: really wordy explanation for a dozen-line change
column26: but the two issues there are subtle
column27: and I wanted to capture them somewhere.§2493§6 § `webext_storage::Store::close` landed in https://github.com/mozilla/application-services/pull/3042
column28: let's upgrade our vendored a-s version to support that.One thing I've been thinking about over the last couple of days is how to handle errors from `close`/`teardown`. Rusqlite connections have a [`Drop` implementation](https://github.com/rusqlite/rusqlite/blob/65ef2224b6c36ee7d298331ee45349844a8bed80/src/inner_connection.rs#L298-L311) that tries to automatically close the connection
column29: and panic if that fails. On Desktop
column34: dropping the last reference to a Rust `StorageSyncArea` XPCOM class without calling `teardown` will drop its `LazyStore`
column37: which drops its `InnerConnection`...which closes the connection on the main thread.While this isn't ideal
column38: I think it's OK as a last resort—especially since mozStorage does [something similar](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/2bfe3415fb3a2fba9b1c694bc0b376365e086927/storage/mozStorageConnection.cpp#541-543). Consumers should always call `teardown` explicitly
column39: and not rely on automatic cleanup by the last reference falling out of scope. As Mark points out in [this comment](https://github.com/mozilla/application-services/pull/3042#discussion_r416404414)
column40: "the last reference falling out of scope" is a hazy concept
column41: because XPCOM objects in JS are GCed—meaning XPConnect will release the object sometime later
column42: not immediately.It's also an edge case within an edge case: 1) we'll only synchronously close the connection on the main thread if a) someone is misusing a `StorageSyncArea`
column43: which shouldn't happen given that we have our `StorageSyncService` always holding one strong reference
column44: and that's what Sync and `ExtensionStorageSync.jsm` go through
column45: or b) dispatching the `teardown` runnable fails
column46: which should only happen at shutdown
column48: anyway...and 2) we'll only crash if `close` itself fails
column49: which it shouldn't given that we serialize all operations on the task queue
column50: and `rusqlite::Connection::close` already cleans up cached statements before trying to close the connection.That's a really
column51: really wordy explanation for a dozen-line change

column5: that I hope you can help with.  I am developing on a ColdFusion website
column6: and serving an MP3 file via the CFCONTENT tag.The MP3 file is created by the server using the DOS command copy (ie. "copy -b x.mp3 + y.mp3 xy.mp3")
column7: so the mp3 files are created using this DOS binary append method; as such I know that the mp3 files may not have the 'correct' headers in the file
column8: but this doesn't seem to matter at all in IE 7 (Windows
column9: using the WMP plugin)

column11: because when I use the same code but reference the SRC to the actual location of the mp3 file
column12: it works fine in all browsers mentioned above and in this problem setup on Mac.The URL provided will show the only situation that I have been able to get it to work properly

1632283 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Components § 11 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§IpdlQueue can batch at least most async WebGL messages to the compositor process.  This will lead to far fewer IPDL Send calls and improve latency is many cases.  The async buffer should be flushed on (1) a synchronous call or (2) on demand.  We'll need something like a recurring task that flushes to make sure that we don't starve the buffer.§345§1 § IpdlQueue can batch at least most async WebGL messages to the compositor process.  This will lead to far fewer IPDL Send calls and improve latency is many cases.  The async buffer should be flushed on (1) a synchronous call or (2) on demand.  We'll need something like a recurring task that flushes to make sure that we don't starve the buffer. § 2020-04-22T20:15:00Z § 2020-06-02T03:27:07Z

column8:
Carole Anne Ford

Coal Hill School teachers Ian Chesterton and Barbara Wright are baffled by a teenage pupil of theirs
column9: Susan Foreman. Brilliant in many subjects
column10: atrocious in others
column11: she has behaved strangely ever since she arrived at the school. One evening
column12: their curiosity gets the better of them
column13:
and the teachers follow her home - to a junkyard that holds a battered Police Telephone Box. It is the key to an adventure that will change their lives forever.
 
Following Susan into the yard they meet her grandfather
column14: a mysterious old man who refuses to deal with their questions. But when they force their way into the Police Box
column15:
they discover that it is merely the disguise for an unimaginably advanced space and time machine - one that Susan's grandfather seems deterimed to activate...
 
Hurtling through time into Earth's savage past
column16:
Ian and Barbara must rely on their wits to stay alive. But can the mysterious Dr. Foreman be trusted - and will he ever be able to return them to their rightful time and space?

1629663 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Components § 2 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§We found another KDF function in libreswan that is not using the NSS KDF API.Unfortunately
column2: it seems the existing IKE KDF's in NSS are not usable for the Quick Mode use. The libreswan code is in compute_proto_keymat() and the specification is in  https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2409#section-5.5  It needs:   KEYMAT = prf(SKEYID_d
column3: [g(qm)^xy ] | protocol | SPI | Ni_b | Nr_b). which an be thought of as:   KEYMAT = prf(KEY
column4: [KEY] | BYTES) but with the kicker that it also does multiple rounds aka key expansion:       KEYMAT = K1 | K2 | K3 | ...       where         K1 = prf(KEY
column5: [KEY] | BYTES)        K2 = prf(KEY
column6: K1 | [KEY] | BYTES)        K3 = prf(KEY

column1: 336807 § INVALID § critical § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 16 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1. ulimit -Sv 530002. /usr/bin/firefox  (with a minimal profile
column2: e.g. home = about:blank)3. Enter URL: http://www.nytimes.com/§129§3§None§ 0§ 0§1) Never crash.2) Not perform an action which is useless (e.g. opening a window which cannot be used
column3: warn if navigating forward will disallow navigating back
column4: etc).3) Fail gracefully for excessive requests (e.g. if one wants to display a huge image but can't allocate memory for it
column5: one should still be able to figure out how big the image would be
column6: properly tell the display manager to block out that space
column7: and provide some text in its place
column8: e.g. "Place for 10MB image 'my-really-big-img.jpg'"The fact that these bugs exist at this state of Firefox development and "production" release shows an extreme disregard for stress testing
column9: particularly with regard to memory usage.  When problems started being reported with Firefox memory usage (some of which are memory leaks but many of which are heap fragmentation problems) one of the first questions which should have been examined was "Does Firefox fail gracefully under severe memory constraints?"  It does not appear that that has been done.The reason for this is as follows.  Most people are not going to bother watching Firefox memory usage (using top / vmstat / System Monitor).  Instead they might want to receive "reasonable" warnings when memory consumption has gotten out of hand (Linux system performance goes down the tubes when the Firefox resident memory requirements exceed 60-70% of physical memory).  Though this is a Linux paging problem
column10: it is ascerbated by Firefox's poor heap memory management causing execessive paging.  One obvious solution is to limit Firefox so its virtual memory requirements can never exceed 50-60% of physical memory.  This is what the ulimits are for (one could even have the script /usr/bin/firefox preset the virtual memory limit!).  If Firefox then warned the user -- but did *not* fail or exit -- the user would (a) be aware of pages which may be memory hogs; and (b) choose to continue browsing with perhaps some degradation in performance or (c) restart Firefox to reinitialize (compactify) the heap.The flexibility of constraining Firefox using the Linux Soft & Hard memory limits is a very reasonable way to manage the browser.  (I.e. there should be some config flag to allow Firefox to push the soft limits up to the hard limits.)  [I suspect the ability to set ulimits is also available with Solaris and perhaps even Mac OS X -- so this approach would only not work under Windows.]Tests under memory constraints should include:1) Browsing to a new page (when memory for the "history" allocation fails).2) Opening "Manage Bookmarks" under tight constraints (use Firefox with an empty bookmarks file
column11: then replace it with one which is 2-5MB).3) Opening lots of new windows (Ctrl-N)4) Opening lots of new tabs (Ctrl-T)5) Saving pages (requires opening files)6) Downloading a binary files (requires starting the download manager)7) Opening successively more difficult windows
column12: e.g. (a) a blank page; (b) a text page with various simple fonts; (c) a text page with small images; (d) a text page with small images and style sheets; (e) a text page with javascript; (f) a text page with images & javascript; (g) a page which requires starting Java (presumably may require resetting the ulimit if it drags in additional shared libraries); (h) any of the various pages with streamed or direct video
column13: etc.In cases where the action involves page display it should give me *all* of the page which is possible
column14: e.g. a page with a big image followed by a large number of small images should *still* give me the small images even if the big image will not fit into memory.  If there isn't memory for a large Javascript or a Style Sheet
column15: give me as much of the page as you can without them. column16: the most obvious of which is "crashing" with a segmentation fault.There are indications that little or no stress testing has been done on Firefox with constrained memory. column18: e.g. home = about:blank)3. Enter URL: http://www.nytimes.com/Actual Actual results:  Firefox crashes and starts the bug reporting agent.One wants to limit the available virtual memory to just slightly above that required to start firefox and test the limits of various functions.  If the available memory is set too low one cannot map the libraries but at slightly above that one should be able to "stress" all various aspects of memory allocation/management.Attempting to test various options I have seen at least the following problems:1. Crashes on opening pages.2. Crashes on Bookmarks >> Manage Bookmarks (with only about 10 small bookmarks)3. Fails to open a functional new window (Ctrl-N will open a window but you can't use it for navigation
column19: it ends up with a grey background rather than a white background -- in theory one shouldn't open a non-functional window).4. Specifying a new URL will allow navigation to a new page but will not navigate back (hitting the back button does nothing).Expected Actual results:  1) Never crash.2) Not perform an action which is useless (e.g. opening a window which cannot be used
column20: warn if navigating forward will disallow navigating back
column21: etc).3) Fail gracefully for excessive requests (e.g. if one wants to display a huge image but can't allocate memory for it
column22: one should still be able to figure out how big the image would be
column23: properly tell the display manager to block out that space
column24: and provide some text in its place
column25: e.g. "Place for 10MB image 'my-really-big-img.jpg'"The fact that these bugs exist at this state of Firefox development and "production" release shows an extreme disregard for stress testing
column26: particularly with regard to memory usage.  When problems started being reported with Firefox memory usage (some of which are memory leaks but many of which are heap fragmentation problems) one of the first questions which should have been examined was "Does Firefox fail gracefully under severe memory constraints?"  It does not appear that that has been done.The reason for this is as follows.  Most people are not going to bother watching Firefox memory usage (using top / vmstat / System Monitor).  Instead they might want to receive "reasonable" warnings when memory consumption has gotten out of hand (Linux system performance goes down the tubes when the Firefox resident memory requirements exceed 60-70% of physical memory).  Though this is a Linux paging problem
column27: it is ascerbated by Firefox's poor heap memory management causing execessive paging.  One obvious solution is to limit Firefox so its virtual memory requirements can never exceed 50-60% of physical memory.  This is what the ulimits are for (one could even have the script /usr/bin/firefox preset the virtual memory limit!).  If Firefox then warned the user -- but did *not* fail or exit -- the user would (a) be aware of pages which may be memory hogs; and (b) choose to continue browsing with perhaps some degradation in performance or (c) restart Firefox to reinitialize (compactify) the heap.The flexibility of constraining Firefox using the Linux Soft & Hard memory limits is a very reasonable way to manage the browser.  (I.e. there should be some config flag to allow Firefox to push the soft limits up to the hard limits.)  [I suspect the ability to set ulimits is also available with Solaris and perhaps even Mac OS X -- so this approach would only not work under Windows.]Tests under memory constraints should include:1) Browsing to a new page (when memory for the "history" allocation fails).2) Opening "Manage Bookmarks" under tight constraints (use Firefox with an empty bookmarks file
column28: then replace it with one which is 2-5MB).3) Opening lots of new windows (Ctrl-N)4) Opening lots of new tabs (Ctrl-T)5) Saving pages (requires opening files)6) Downloading a binary files (requires starting the download manager)7) Opening successively more difficult windows

column1: 831211 § WONTFIX § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 9 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.7; rv:21.0) Gecko/20130115 Firefox/21.0Switching between the active and disabled state of pdf.js can leave the feature permanently disabled. This would cause us problems when we have to turn it off
column2: which hopefully will not happen. But just in case it would be helpful to have it fixed.Steps:1. Create a fresh profile2. Disable pdf.js via about:config3. Open preferences and select an external application for the pdf mimetype4. Load a PDF: www.gesetze-im-internet.de/bundesrecht/bgb/gesamt.pdf5. Enable pdf.js6. Reload the above PDFAfter step 6 we no longer use pdf.js as the mimetype handler but still open the PDF with the selected externally application. As workaround you would have to reset 'pdfjs.migrationVersion' and restart the browser.Asking for blocking 19.0 because it breaks the enable/disable logic of a new feature in Firefox.§895§11 § Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.7; rv:21.0) Gecko/20130115 Firefox/21.0Switching between the active and disabled state of pdf.js can leave the feature permanently disabled. This would cause us problems when we have to turn it off
column3: which hopefully will not happen. But just in case it would be helpful to have it fixed.Steps:1. Create a fresh profile2. Disable pdf.js via about:config3. Open preferences and select an external application for the pdf mimetype4. Load a PDF: www.gesetze-im-internet.de/bundesrecht/bgb/gesamt.pdf5. Enable pdf.js6. Reload the above PDFAfter step 6 we no longer use pdf.js as the mimetype handler but still open the PDF with the selected externally application. As workaround you would have to reset 'pdfjs.migrationVersion' and restart the browser.Asking for blocking 19.0 because it breaks the enable/disable logic of a new feature in Firefox. § 2013-01-16T11:31:59Z § 2013-01-28T21:14:52Z

column1: 234734 § FIXED § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 4 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1.Search for something on google2.return to google homepage3.type the first few letters of your previous search and try to click onautocomplete result that comes up with left mouse button§191§4§None§ 0§ 0§should've autocomplete'd the entry§35§1§: Always§9§1§:       Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7a) Gecko/20040217 Firefox/0.8.0+ (scragz)see below

column3: also see URL for some commentsReproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1.Search for something on google2.return to google homepage3.type the first few letters of your previous search and try to click onautocomplete result that comes up with left mouse buttonActual Actual results:  does not autocomplete the entry when using muose
column4: only when using keyboardproduces an error in JS console:Error: uncaught exception: [Exception... "Cannot modify properties of aWrappedNative"  nsresult: "0x80570034 (NS_ERROR_XPC_CANT_MODIFY_PROP_ON_WN)" location: "JS frame :: chrome://global/content/bindings/autocomplete.xml ::onPopupClick :: line 604"  data: no]Expected Actual results:  should've autocomplete'd the entry § 2004-02-18T05:00:18Z § 2004-02-18T11:38:33Z

column1: 1438571 § FIXED § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 4 § P4 § Windows 10 64bit.macOS 10.13.Ubuntu 16.04 64bit.§51§3§None§ 0§ 0§1. Launch Firefox with a clean profile.2. Access the about:preferences#containers page.3. Click the "Preferences" button from one of the available container.4. Fill the "Name" field with a long text.5. Click the "Done" button.6  Click the "Preferences" button of the modified container.7. Try to change the previously entered name.§338§7§The user can successfully change the container name.§53§1§The Container window is displayed overly stretched and the user is not able to change the container name because:- The "Done" button is no longer displayed (even if resizing the window).- The "Enter" keyboard button doesn't save any changes.The user is eventually forced to delete that particular container.[Regression range]:I don't think that this is a regression.[Note]For further information regarding this issue please observe the attached screencast.§464§8§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§[Affected versions]:60.0a1 (BuildId:20180215103933)59.0b9 (BuildId:20180209162511)58.0.2 (BuildId:20180206200532)52.6.0 esr (BuildId:20180118122319)§153§5 § [Affected versions]:60.0a1 (BuildId:20180215103933)59.0b9 (BuildId:20180209162511)58.0.2 (BuildId:20180206200532)52.6.0 esr (BuildId:20180118122319)[Affected platforms]:Windows 10 64bit.macOS 10.13.Ubuntu 16.04 64bit.[Steps to reproduce]:1. Launch Firefox with a clean profile.2. Access the about:preferences#containers page.3. Click the "Preferences" button from one of the available container.4. Fill the "Name" field with a long text.5. Click the "Done" button.6  Click the "Preferences" button of the modified container.7. Try to change the previously entered name.[Expected result]:The user can successfully change the container name.[Actual result]:The Container window is displayed overly stretched and the user is not able to change the container name because:- The "Done" button is no longer displayed (even if resizing the window).- The "Enter" keyboard button doesn't save any changes.The user is eventually forced to delete that particular container.[Regression range]:I don't think that this is a regression.[Note]For further information regarding this issue please observe the attached screencast. § 2018-02-15T16:57:18Z § 2021-03-25T01:44:54Z

1641796 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Components § 16 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§We now support service workers in the target list for content toolboxes. But we don't handle top level target navigation correctly.Imagine you have 2 service workers
column2: sw-a.js for domain-a.com
column3: sw-b.js for domain-b.com.And imagine both workers (and registrations) are already available when the toolbox starts.If you start listening for service worker targets while the toolbox debugs a tab on domain-a.com
column4: the target list will filter out `sw-b.js` and make call the onTargetAvailable callback for `sw-a.js`. But if you navigate to domain-b.com
column5: then `sw-a.js` is no longer relevant but `sw-b.js` becomes relevant! However in terms of real "targets" no target has been created or destroyed. ### Potential solutionsIt's not completely clear to me how much of this should be handled by the target list and how much should be handled by the consumers. #### Navigation (target-list)For the navigation scenario above
column6: it's pretty clear that target list should handle this complexity. Which means that when we navigate
column7: we should call onTargetDestroyed for all the service worker targets that no longer match the current target's domain
column8: and call onTargetAvailable for the ones which now match the domain.#### Reload (target-list or consumer?)But what about a regular reload scenario? In the case of the debugger
column9: the whole source tree is cleared when navigating. Regular sources that are linked to the window lifecycle will be recreated and will populate the debugger. But the service worker is not created or destroyed here. Here I see two options:- target list could go a step further and call onTargetDestroyed for all service worker targets on will-navigate
column10: and then call onTargetAvailable on navigate- or the panel could preserve the service worker targets
column11: and trust that onTargetDestroyed/Available will be called in case there was a real navigation and the list of targets corresponding to the top target actually changed§1937§12§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Follow up to Bug 1621337.This was initially spotted while reviewing Bug 1621338. If you have a debugger opened on a page with service workers
column12: reloading the page will make the service worker sources disappear.§211§2 § Follow up to Bug 1621337.This was initially spotted while reviewing Bug 1621338. If you have a debugger opened on a page with service workers
column13: reloading the page will make the service worker sources disappear.### Steps to reproducesWe now support service workers in the target list for content toolboxes. But we don't handle top level target navigation correctly.Imagine you have 2 service workers
column14: sw-a.js for domain-a.com
column15: sw-b.js for domain-b.com.And imagine both workers (and registrations) are already available when the toolbox starts.If you start listening for service worker targets while the toolbox debugs a tab on domain-a.com
column16: the target list will filter out `sw-b.js` and make call the onTargetAvailable callback for `sw-a.js`. But if you navigate to domain-b.com
column17: then `sw-a.js` is no longer relevant but `sw-b.js` becomes relevant! However in terms of real "targets" no target has been created or destroyed. ### Potential solutionsIt's not completely clear to me how much of this should be handled by the target list and how much should be handled by the consumers. #### Navigation (target-list)For the navigation scenario above
column18: it's pretty clear that target list should handle this complexity. Which means that when we navigate
column19: we should call onTargetDestroyed for all the service worker targets that no longer match the current target's domain
column20: and call onTargetAvailable for the ones which now match the domain.#### Reload (target-list or consumer?)But what about a regular reload scenario? In the case of the debugger
column21: the whole source tree is cleared when navigating. Regular sources that are linked to the window lifecycle will be recreated and will populate the debugger. But the service worker is not created or destroyed here. Here I see two options:- target list could go a step further and call onTargetDestroyed for all service worker targets on will-navigate
column22: and then call onTargetAvailable on navigate- or the panel could preserve the service worker targets
column23: and trust that onTargetDestroyed/Available will be called in case there was a real navigation and the list of targets corresponding to the top target actually changed § 2020-05-29T09:23:47Z § 2021-02-09T00:20:04Z

column1: 1632139 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Components § 4 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Currently the GC heap thresholds for each zone are recalculated:  1) Once when we finish foreground sweeping in the zone
column2: and then  2) Periodically when sweeping background things in the zoneSince the threashold is based on the retained GC bytes in the zone and this value is not correct until background sweeping has finished
column3: the value calculated for a zone changes substantially over the course of a single GC.  Specifically
column4: there is a large increase in the threshold when forground sweeping finishes and then it falls linearly as more data is freed until it reaches its final value.It would make more sense to calculate this once at the end
column5: when the size of retained data is know
column6: but when we tried that we discovered that some benchmarks (mainly splay latency) rely on the current behaviour.Splay is a benchmark that contantly allocates
column7: yet the size of reachable data remains roughly constant.  Currently we end up triggering incremental GC slices which allows us to have a resonable score on the latency part of the benchmark.The effect of only recalculating zone thresholds at the end of the GC is that we exceed the non-incremental threshold during the GC
column8: and this introduces pauses that greatly reduce our latency score.  This is because the initial increase in the threshold prevents non-incremental GC from kicking in while we are sweeping.The solution to all of this is probably to raise the non-incremental threshold
column9: but I don't want to do that until we've got some fallback in place to make sure the GC is keeping up with allocation.  Instead the aim of this bug is to calculate the thresholds once at the end but add an explicit hack to increase the non-incremental threshold during background sweeping so that we don't regress our benchmark scores.§1777§8 § Currently the GC heap thresholds for each zone are recalculated:  1) Once when we finish foreground sweeping in the zone
column10: and then  2) Periodically when sweeping background things in the zoneSince the threashold is based on the retained GC bytes in the zone and this value is not correct until background sweeping has finished
column11: the value calculated for a zone changes substantially over the course of a single GC.  Specifically
column12: there is a large increase in the threshold when forground sweeping finishes and then it falls linearly as more data is freed until it reaches its final value.It would make more sense to calculate this once at the end
column13: when the size of retained data is know
column14: but when we tried that we discovered that some benchmarks (mainly splay latency) rely on the current behaviour.Splay is a benchmark that contantly allocates
column15: yet the size of reachable data remains roughly constant.  Currently we end up triggering incremental GC slices which allows us to have a resonable score on the latency part of the benchmark.The effect of only recalculating zone thresholds at the end of the GC is that we exceed the non-incremental threshold during the GC
column16: and this introduces pauses that greatly reduce our latency score.  This is because the initial increase in the threshold prevents non-incremental GC from kicking in while we are sweeping.The solution to all of this is probably to raise the non-incremental threshold
column17: but I don't want to do that until we've got some fallback in place to make sure the GC is keeping up with allocation.  Instead the aim of this bug is to calculate the thresholds once at the end but add an explicit hack to increase the non-incremental threshold during background sweeping so that we don't regress our benchmark scores. § 2020-04-22T13:34:35Z § 2020-04-24T16:32:53Z

column1: 505656 § FIXED § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 41 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1. Create a new profile2. Remove all bookmarks via the bookmark manager3. Choose "Backup" from the bookmark manager toolbar§126§3§None§ 0§ 0§A valid JSON file is produced.§31§1§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9.2a1pre) Gecko/20090721 Minefield/3.6a1preBuild Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9.2a1pre) Gecko/20090721 Minefield/3.6a1pre§234§2§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9.2a1pre) Gecko/20090721 Minefield/3.6a1preBuild Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9.2a1pre) Gecko/20090721 Minefield/3.6a1preThe bookmarks backup JSON file created daily in the profile directory is not valid JSON.  It contains a trailing comma
column2: which makes JSON parsers barf
column3: including http://code.google.com/p/json-framework/ (Mac OS X/Cocoa) and http://www.jsonlint.com/ (Web).  A similar bug was reported for the built-in JSON serialization facility: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=426718 .  That bug is no longer reproducible (i.e. fixed?) on the latest nightly.  However the bookmarks backup code still uses manual JSON generation.  The problem function appears to be serializeNodeAsJSONToOutputStream at mozilla/toolkit/components/places/src/utils.js:1490 .  I believe that the offending comma is written by line 1626 of that file.Reproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1. Create a new profile2. Remove all bookmarks via the bookmark manager3. Choose "Backup" from the bookmark manager toolbarActual Actual results:  An invalid JSON file is produced.  I will attempt (as I've never used bugzilla before) to attache this file to this reportExpected Actual results:  A valid JSON file is produced. § 2009-07-22T04:17:43Z § 2013-10-17T06:35:15Z

column1: 1196151 § FIXED § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 17 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1. Register a custom protocol handler using navigator.registerProtocolHandler.2. Set an iframe's src to a URI of the custom protocol.Attached repro.zip which creates these conditions. To use it:1. Serve on localhost:8000 (eg. python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8000).2. Navigate to http://localhost:8000. A bar appears at the top; click Add Application to add the site as a handler for "web+foo" links.3. Click "click here". A dialog appears
column2: asking which application to use. Choose Protocol Handler Test.§503§6§The handler page ("I just handled the protocol") appears inside the iframe.Note: The spec [1] says "In the case of a registered handler being used
column3: the algorithm will be reinvoked with a new URL to handle the request." I take this to mean that when an iframe navigates to a registered protocol handler
column4: it should calculate the new URL and then redirect the page within the iframe
column5: not create a new top-level browsing context.[1] https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsers.html#navigateWorks correctly in Google Chrome 46.§530§4§The handler page ("I just handled the protocol") opens in a new tab.§69§1§None§ 0§ 0§: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML

column9: the algorithm will be reinvoked with a new URL to handle the request." I take this to mean that when an iframe navigates to a registered protocol handler

column1: 292805 § INVALID § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1. Click icon to open Mozilla Firefox v1.7.7.2. Startpage of browser opens up.3. Same thing happens when I go to all other websites.§135§3§None§ 0§ 0§Open all websites to make use of the full screen of my display as itdid before I installed the Extensions and Add-ons for Firefox v1.7.7§138§2§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.7) Gecko/20050414 Firefox/1.0.3 (ax)Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.7) Gecko/20050414 Firefox/1.0.3 (ax)I just downloaded Firefox v1.7.7 and added various extensions and add-ons andnow when I open the browesr page to either the firefox 1.7.7 homepage or anyother website only the top 1/3 of the screen shows a website then there is ahorizontal line going across the screen and the rest of the screen is white.The top of the screen that shows the website also has a scroll bar to scrolldown but the area you can see is so small it doesn't even help.I tried to uninstall some of the extensions with the extension uninstaller underthe Tools menu and it says I need to install the Extension Uninstaller API andwhen I click to install it I get the following message:  "Script Error" andit doesn't install and I can't uninstall anything.I also tried uninstalling Firefox 1.7.7 alltogether from my computer and then Itried to re-install it and all webpages still open the same way.Please help !Sincerely
column2: Dan Garfinkel§1131§17§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.7) Gecko/20050414 Firefox/1.0.3 (ax)Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.7) Gecko/20050414 Firefox/1.0.3 (ax)I just downloaded Firefox v1.7.7 and added various extensions and add-ons andnow when I open the browesr page to either the firefox 1.7.7 homepage or anyother website only the top 1/3 of the screen shows a website then there is ahorizontal line going across the screen and the rest of the screen is white.The top of the screen that shows the website also has a scroll bar to scrolldown but the area you can see is so small it doesn't even help.I tried to uninstall some of the extensions with the extension uninstaller underthe Tools menu and it says I need to install the Extension Uninstaller API andwhen I click to install it I get the following message:  "Script Error" andit doesn't install and I can't uninstall anything.I also tried uninstalling Firefox 1.7.7 alltogether from my computer and then Itried to re-install it and all webpages still open the same way.Please help !Sincerely
column3: Dan GarfinkelReproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1. Click icon to open Mozilla Firefox v1.7.7.2. Startpage of browser opens up.3. Same thing happens when I go to all other websites.Actual Actual results:  The problem described above occurs.Expected Actual results:  Open all websites to make use of the full screen of my display as itdid before I installed the Extensions and Add-ons for Firefox v1.7.7 § 2005-05-04T00:27:04Z § 2005-05-26T04:54:11Z

column2: you will see that an <object> is defined and used in the web page.  FF2 does not recognize or load/build this object and there is no error evident from FF2.  FF2 Help does not have an "iframe" topic to show me what settings need to be tweeked to make this work in FF2.  In IE6 this object creates a 240x230 pixel video window that in-turn connects to and shows what may be a windows media player A/V stream (see the MMS://xxxxx links).  §711§3§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8.1.1) Gecko/20061204 Firefox/2.0.0.1Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8.1.1) Gecko/20061204 Firefox/2.0.0.1Hi. column3: you will see that an <object> is defined and used in the web page.  FF2 does not recognize or load/build this object and there is no error evident from FF2.  FF2 Help does not have an "iframe" topic to show me what settings need to be tweeked to make this work in FF2.  In IE6 this object creates a 240x230 pixel video window that in-turn connects to and shows what may be a windows media player A/V stream (see the MMS://xxxxx links).  Reproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1. Hit www.srilaprabhupad.info/webcast.htm with FF2.2. Hit www.srilaprabhupad.info/webcast.htm with IE6 or 7.3. Compare the displayed differences.  4. View source for FF2.  Actual Actual results:  FF2 fails to display the 240x230 video window.  However
column4: I can launch Win Media Player application in it's own window from 2 of the other clearly-displayed buttons on the page.  Expected Actual results:  The video window should display on the targeted page using FF2I think I'm using the default theme. § 2007-02-06T03:47:11Z § 2010-09-15T17:18:37Z

Most of this could be saved if the method was made incremental
column2: especially caching the forecast models rather than recomputing them using historical MAU each day.  This will add complexity beyond what I feel it is reasonable for Data Science to maintain
column3: so would recommend that Data Engineering take ownership of the pipeline. column5: selecting File
column6: and selecting File Open in the menu

column1: 1632204 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Components § 8 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Download the testcase and run: `python3 -m http.server`Open the developer tools (Network) and navigate to http://localhost:8000/testcase.htmlThis will send a XHR request to the same origin on a page where Referrer-Policy: no-referrer is applied.What happened:Request headers include:```Origin: nullSec-Fetch-Dest: emptySec-Fetch-Mode: corsSec-Fetch-Site: same-origin```§380§11§The request header should be this (matches Firefox 75.0):```Origin: http://localhost:8000```Additional information:This change was bisected to https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/autoland/rev/a925b80f029e3f2107a91bde02e9799fb9821eb3 (application_buildid: 20200420201907)It breaks search functionality on a Confluence wiki page where this referrer-policy is set.§367§7§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§§0§0 § Steps to reproduce:Download the testcase and run: `python3 -m http.server`Open the developer tools (Network) and navigate to http://localhost:8000/testcase.htmlThis will send a XHR request to the same origin on a page where Referrer-Policy: no-referrer is applied.What happened:Request headers include:```Origin: nullSec-Fetch-Dest: emptySec-Fetch-Mode: corsSec-Fetch-Site: same-origin```Expected results:The request header should be this (matches Firefox 75.0):```Origin: http://localhost:8000```Additional information:This change was bisected to https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/autoland/rev/a925b80f029e3f2107a91bde02e9799fb9821eb3 (application_buildid: 20200420201907)It breaks search functionality on a Confluence wiki page where this referrer-policy is set. § 2020-04-22T15:21:50Z § 2020-04-29T00:56:56Z

column1: 1638108 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Client Software § 2 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§#### Bug Fixes*   don't consider expiry during batch commit (#632) ([90ff7485](https://github.com/mozilla-services/syncstorage-rs/commit/90ff74858f10f5e52f1acd60a57f6a2ead46c891))FYI:The above mentioned issue (expired data that has not been purged conflicting with data uploaded in batches
column2: triggering an AlreadyExists error) has caught some clients who have been repeatedly failing to sync
column3: w/ the AlreadyExists giving them 500 errors. This usually hits their history collection.They should now successfully sync. We may see more batch commits succeeding temporarily as they "catch up". It doesn't seem to have affected very many users (per the 500 rates it's produced). I don't foresee us noticing the "catching up" other than the lowering of 500 rates.§760§5 § #### Bug Fixes*   don't consider expiry during batch commit (#632) ([90ff7485](https://github.com/mozilla-services/syncstorage-rs/commit/90ff74858f10f5e52f1acd60a57f6a2ead46c891))FYI:The above mentioned issue (expired data that has not been purged conflicting with data uploaded in batches
column4: triggering an AlreadyExists error) has caught some clients who have been repeatedly failing to sync
column5: w/ the AlreadyExists giving them 500 errors. This usually hits their history collection.They should now successfully sync. We may see more batch commits succeeding temporarily as they "catch up". It doesn't seem to have affected very many users (per the 500 rates it's produced). I don't foresee us noticing the "catching up" other than the lowering of 500 rates. § 2020-05-14T19:50:46Z § 2020-05-18T14:18:01Z

column1: 1637914 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Client Software § 2 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Now that we have gzip-compression for pings we require the language implementations to decode it on the fly for logging.That requires them to have a gzip implementation.But since we have the upload mechanism controlled on the Rust side now
column2: we know _when_ upload happens (when the uploader requests it)
column3: we can move logging back to Rust!(On top of that: we have the data uncompressed on the Rust side so no back-and-forth just for logging)Care needs to be taken to split the logging across lines
column4: as we do on Android to adhere to the log buffer limits.§557§5 § Now that we have gzip-compression for pings we require the language implementations to decode it on the fly for logging.That requires them to have a gzip implementation.But since we have the upload mechanism controlled on the Rust side now
column5: we know _when_ upload happens (when the uploader requests it)
column6: we can move logging back to Rust!(On top of that: we have the data uncompressed on the Rust side so no back-and-forth just for logging)Care needs to be taken to split the logging across lines
column7: as we do on Android to adhere to the log buffer limits. § 2020-05-14T09:53:19Z § 2020-05-25T08:51:30Z

column1: 1631576 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Components § 28 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§[filed from mail to security@ from Cesar Pereida Garcia]Dear NSS and Red Hat folks
column2: We are a team of security researchers in Finland and we would like to report a vulnerability affecting the DSA signature generation path in NSS. The vulnerability leaks enough information to recover DSA private keys via a timing attack and a lattice calculation.### Timing attack strikes once more ###Affecting NSS latests branch.This attack draws inspiration from the attacks presented in [1] and [2].During DSA signature generation in the function `dsa_SignDigest`
column3: the nonce value `k` is not padded
column4: exposing the bit length of `k`
column5: i.e. the most significant bits (MSBs) of the nonce.Similar to [1]
column6: the regularity of the modular exponentiation function `mp_exptmod_safe_i` processing the nonce
column7: amplifies and improves thetiming resolution
column8: allowing to clearly distinguish the time it takes to generate a signature
column9: and therefore leaking the MSBs.Moreover
column10: due to the windowed approach used by the modular exponentiation algorithm
column11: nonce bits are processed in windows of 4 bits
column12: thus the leakage occurs in multiples of 4 bits.An attacker can measure the time it takes to compute a DSA signature and then based on the time
column13: catalog in buckets.The attacker can label each bucket with length `n - (4 * i)` bits
column14: where `n` is the length of the DSA private key
column15: and `i` is the amountof windows skipped by the algorithm due to smaller nonce length.The attached figure shows experimental results with a DSA key generated with default parameters using the `certutil` tool
column16: i.e. 2048-bit DSA witha 224-bit private key length. As can be appreciated
column17: the timing difference is clearly marked
column18: allowing to easily categorize signatures in each bucketto then proceed with the lattice calculation to finally recover the private key.### Vulnerable applications ###This vulnerability can be exploited by any application performing DSA signatures and using NSS as the cryptography library.We include Red Hat folks in the loop as they very likely have several tools and applications linking to NSS to perform DSA operations.### Countermeasure ###We recommend padding the nonce `k` value to be of fixed length
column20: resulting in no leakage by the modular exponentiationfunction.We can help develop and/or test the patch
column22: please let us know how would you like to proceed.### Disclosure ###We aim a public disclosure of our findings on May 18 (~1 month from today). We appreciate if you could take a look at this issue at your earliestconvenience.### References ###[1] Billy Bob Brumley and Nicola Tuveri. “Remote Timing Attacks Are Still Practical”. In Computer Security - ESORICS 2011.[2] Cesar Pereida
column24: and Yuval Yarom. "Make sure DSA signing exponentiations really are constant-time". In 23rd CCS
column25: 2016.Thanks for your time reviewing this vulnerability.Regards

column1: 1637008 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§With **tail=false** (prioritize completeness over the most recent events) and using min_id as a checkpoint this *should* prevent us from missing anything but that doesn't appear to be the case. Papertrail provides no data consistency or latency SLA's; maybe we should try reading data that is only X minutes old and see if that helps.§335§1 § With **tail=false** (prioritize completeness over the most recent events) and using min_id as a checkpoint this *should* prevent us from missing anything but that doesn't appear to be the case. Papertrail provides no data consistency or latency SLA's; maybe we should try reading data that is only X minutes old and see if that helps. § 2020-05-11T16:39:11Z § 2020-06-23T14:34:49Z

column1: 390227 § INCOMPLETE § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § -- § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1.[HTML within a form] §166§1§None§ 0§ 0§It is as though the button behaviour masks the desired img behaviour.I would like the img events to behave in the same way with or without the button tag. Any 3D button behaviour should not interfere with them.This is to enable a form element to have an image and a tabindex
column2: without acting as a submit button (so input button and input image are no good).This might be more of a feature than a bug
column3: but if so it would be helpful to have some documentation of the button action or a suggestion of a workaround.§514§4§: Always§9§1§:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-GB; rv:1.8.1.5) Gecko/20070713 Firefox/2.0.0.5Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-GB; rv:1.8.1.5) Gecko/20070713 Firefox/2.0.0.5I need to have an HTML img tag inside a button tag (please see reasons below). But mouse events on the img tag do not work as they should in this situation. If this cannot be fixed
column4: then documentation of the precise action of a button tag might help.§459§3§§0§0 § User Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-GB; rv:1.8.1.5) Gecko/20070713 Firefox/2.0.0.5Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-GB; rv:1.8.1.5) Gecko/20070713 Firefox/2.0.0.5I need to have an HTML img tag inside a button tag (please see reasons below). But mouse events on the img tag do not work as they should in this situation. If this cannot be fixed
column5: then documentation of the precise action of a button tag might help.Reproducible: AlwaysSteps to Reproduce:1.[HTML within a form] Actual Actual results: In Firefox: The onClick and onMouseOver do not execute the JavaScript. Clicking changes the button alignment. alt and title do nothing.In IE6: onMouseOver (only) executes the JavaScript. Clicking changes the button alignment. alt does nothing. title appears only after clicking.Now remove the button start and end tags and repeat.In Firefox: onMouseOver and onClick execute the JavaScript. title appears.In IE6: onMouseOver and onClick execute the JavaScript. onMouseOver fires again after clicking. alt and title do nothing.Expected Actual results: It is as though the button behaviour masks the desired img behaviour.I would like the img events to behave in the same way with or without the button tag. Any 3D button behaviour should not interfere with them.This is to enable a form element to have an image and a tabindex
column6: without acting as a submit button (so input button and input image are no good).This might be more of a feature than a bug
column7: but if so it would be helpful to have some documentation of the button action or a suggestion of a workaround. § 2007-07-30T23:37:17Z § 2010-05-23T00:41:36Z

column1: 1000105 § INVALID § trivial § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 4 § P5 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Attempt to use AutoPushJSContext in a C++ based binary add-on to setup the current JSContext for a call into JS_CallFunctionName.This is required when making a call into Firefox (e.g. to navigate to a URL) from C++ code when a UI element is selected.In earlier versions of Firefox this did not cause a problem because the current JSContext on the context stack was not checked or as heavily used. Binary components could call into JavaScript without pushing the JSContext.§475§3§If the constructor of AutoPushJSContext  were exported then the binary add-on can be linked and correctly call into JavaScript using JS_CallFunctionName.The change would require NS_EXPORT to be added to the AutoPushJSContext constructor in /js/xpconnect/src/nsCxPusher.cpp /js/xpconnect/src/nsCxPusher.h.I have attached modified files to show the proposed changes.§367§3§It's not possible to link the binary add-on as the linker cannot find mozilla::AutoPushJSContext::AutoPushJSContext in xul.lib .Without the JSContext being pushed on the JSContextStack the call is not setup correctly and asserts in XPCCallContext::XPCCallContext on:MOZ_ASSERT(cx == XPCJSRuntime::Get()->GetJSContextStack()->Peek());Also
column2: the security principal is not correctly available for permissions checks (e.g. when adding a new tab).§445§4§None§ 0§ 0§: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; Trident/7.0; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; SLCC2; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET CLR 3.0.30729; Media Center PC 6.0; Tablet PC 2.0; InfoPath.3; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E; MALC; rv:11.0) like Gecko§217§1§§0§0 § User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; Trident/7.0; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; SLCC2; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET CLR 3.0.30729; Media Center PC 6.0; Tablet PC 2.0; InfoPath.3; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E; MALC; rv:11.0) like GeckoSteps to reproduce:Attempt to use AutoPushJSContext in a C++ based binary add-on to setup the current JSContext for a call into JS_CallFunctionName.This is required when making a call into Firefox (e.g. to navigate to a URL) from C++ code when a UI element is selected.In earlier versions of Firefox this did not cause a problem because the current JSContext on the context stack was not checked or as heavily used. Binary components could call into JavaScript without pushing the JSContext.Actual results:It's not possible to link the binary add-on as the linker cannot find mozilla::AutoPushJSContext::AutoPushJSContext in xul.lib .Without the JSContext being pushed on the JSContextStack the call is not setup correctly and asserts in XPCCallContext::XPCCallContext on:MOZ_ASSERT(cx == XPCJSRuntime::Get()->GetJSContextStack()->Peek());Also
column3: the security principal is not correctly available for permissions checks (e.g. when adding a new tab).Expected results:If the constructor of AutoPushJSContext  were exported then the binary add-on can be linked and correctly call into JavaScript using JS_CallFunctionName.The change would require NS_EXPORT to be added to the AutoPushJSContext constructor in /js/xpconnect/src/nsCxPusher.cpp /js/xpconnect/src/nsCxPusher.h.I have attached modified files to show the proposed changes. § 2014-04-23T12:25:15Z § 2014-04-23T13:31:27Z

1630681 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Components § 7 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§As part of rendering the autocomplete popup in the Password Manager on username or password fields
column2: the width of the popup is set based on the width of the corresponding input field in the page or a specified minimum width.Currently
column3: the desired width is obtained by [calling `getBoundingClientRect` on an ancestor node and then setting the `style.width` on the target node](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/a707541ff423ade0d81cef6488e6ecfa09273886/toolkit/content/widgets/autocomplete-richlistitem.js#656-660). This forces [a synchronous layout flush taking on the order of 10ms](https://perfht.ml/3eokTAr) that can likely be avoided
column4: since we already have at least the input field's width from the content process stored in an attribute on another ancestor node.There may be some display issues to resolve with reading the attribute instead in certain situations like when the input field on the page is using a default width
column5: but hopefully those can be addressed
column6: as this would reduce the time it takes to display the autocomplete popup  (Bug 1619498) by a little more than 20% (at least on my machine).§1118§3 § As part of rendering the autocomplete popup in the Password Manager on username or password fields

column1: 960409 § FIXED § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 4 § P3 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§1. Open the attached pdf (2001SimplePages.pdf) using the FF pdf viewer
column2: which is a large number of pages text-only pdf file that only has page numbers for each page. (Note this bug can be duplicated using many pdfs found in the wild
column3: but they are enormous in size
column4: one is the house affordable health care act at  http://housedocs.house.gov/rules/health/111_ahcaa.pdf
column5: and Intel makes such large pdf files for various processor manuals. Interestingly
column6: with just page numbers and only text this is a very large pdf
column7: although much smaller than it would be with content.)2. In the find box enter the number string "2000".3. Wait until the page number 2000 is found and highlighted (can take awhile). 4. Press the next button (down caret).What happens:The find functionality hangs at step 4 showing the swirling busy gif image continuously.What should happen:The message that the find wrapped around to the beginning of the file should appear and the same page "2000" should be highlighted. The busy indicator should halt almost immediately.Further Information:The following console message occurred (using a version of pdf.js used in one of the FF 25 beta builds)************************************************************* Call to xpconnect wrapped JSObject produced this error:  *[Exception... "'[JavaScript Error: "too much recursion" {file: "resource://pdf.js/web/viewer.js" line: 871}]' when calling method: [nsIDOMEventListener::handleEvent]"  nsresult: "0x80570021 (NS_ERROR_XPC_JAVASCRIPT_ERROR_WITH_DETAILS)"  location: "native frame :: <unknown filename> :: <TOP_LEVEL> :: line 0"  data: yes]************************************************************This console error output identifies the function nextPageMatch (at line 871 in that version) which reads:    matchesReady(pageMatches[pageIdx]);The matchesReady function is a local function of nextPageMatch
column8: that in some circumstances calls its parent function nextPageMatch where it reads:        this.nextPageMatch();.While this two-step recursion can only build a stack with two frames for each page of the document
column9: since pdf documents have an unbounded number of pages this can result in an unbounded linear (multiple of two js stack frames per page) stack size and the result is that the recursion is halted by the runtime for such a large pdf and unique find string—throwing an exception. This exception causes a js promise for the find functionality to fail silently
column10: and then the find functionality sits indefinitely in a pending state. While the bugs are distinct and the fixes do not overlap in the code
column11: this bug can appear to be the same or similar to Bug 916876. It is not clear to me whether Bug 916876 has been fixed already by recent work identified in a pdf.js irc conversation
column12: I will figure that out after this bug has been processed. For this bug I already have working code (distinct from my possibly unneeded fix for Bug 916876) that unravels the unbounded recursion into an iteration
column13: and I will isolate just that fix into a pull request shortly. BTW
column14: the iterative implementation executes considerably faster.§3116§22§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§§0§0 § Steps to Reproduce:1. Open the attached pdf (2001SimplePages.pdf) using the FF pdf viewer

column1: 1636176 § FIXED § -- § task § RESOLVED § Client Software § 2 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§FOG provides a Rust API and thus it would like to get to the values stored in a datetime.Internally glean-core stores these as `DateTime<FixedOffset>`s and converts it to a JSON-encoded representation for `test_get_value`.We should expose this type for FOG to consume§270§3 § FOG provides a Rust API and thus it would like to get to the values stored in a datetime.Internally glean-core stores these as `DateTime<FixedOffset>`s and converts it to a JSON-encoded representation for `test_get_value`.We should expose this type for FOG to consume § 2020-05-07T16:23:24Z § 2020-05-27T12:30:18Z

column1: 1631487 § FIXED § -- § enhancement § RESOLVED § Client Software § 4 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§The current telemetry implementation for CFR experiments follows by the convention - a CFR experiment is defined by adding a `cohort` property into the pref json string `browser.newtabpage.activity-stream.asrouter.providers.cfr`.This convention is now invalidated by the new experiment setup with x-man. We should update the CFR telemetry implementation to reflect those changes.§381§2 § The current telemetry implementation for CFR experiments follows by the convention - a CFR experiment is defined by adding a `cohort` property into the pref json string `browser.newtabpage.activity-stream.asrouter.providers.cfr`.This convention is now invalidated by the new experiment setup with x-man. We should update the CFR telemetry implementation to reflect those changes. § 2020-04-20T15:51:36Z § 2020-04-23T10:06:36Z

1503926 § FIXED § normal § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 3 § -- § Windows 10 64bit.§18§1§Enable the "AppUpdateURL" policy via GPO and assign it the following URL: https://www.example.com/§99§1§1. Launch Firefox.2. Access the about:policies page.	§55§2§1: The policy is enabled (enabled via HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE)2: An appropriate error message is displayed inside the about:policies#errors page (enabled via HKEY_CURRENT_USER)- since this is a computer level only policy.§218§2§1 and 2:The "Unknown policy: URL" error is displayed inside the about:policies#errors page.[Note]It seems that the valueName should be "AppUpdateURL" and not just "URL" -> https://github.com/mozilla/policy-templates/blob/master/windows/firefox.admx#L2181 (Thanks Felipe for pointing this out).§296§3§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§[Affected versions]:Firefox 65.0a1 Firefox 64.0b5 Firefox 63.0.1Firefox 60.3.0esr §87§5 § [Affected versions]:Firefox 65.0a1 Firefox 64.0b5 Firefox 63.0.1Firefox 60.3.0esr [Affected platforms]:Windows 10 64bit.[Preconditions]:Enable the "AppUpdateURL" policy via GPO and assign it the following URL: https://www.example.com/[Steps to reproduce]:1. Launch Firefox.2. Access the about:policies page.	[Expected result]:1: The policy is enabled (enabled via HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE)2: An appropriate error message is displayed inside the about:policies#errors page (enabled via HKEY_CURRENT_USER)- since this is a computer level only policy.[Actual result]:1 and 2:The "Unknown policy: URL" error is displayed inside the about:policies#errors page.[Note]It seems that the valueName should be "AppUpdateURL" and not just "URL" -> https://github.com/mozilla/policy-templates/blob/master/windows/firefox.admx#L2181 (Thanks Felipe for pointing this out). § 2018-11-01T16:35:28Z § 2018-12-10T16:55:31Z

1631658 § FIXED § -- § defect § RESOLVED § Client Software § 4 § P1 § None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§None§ 0§ 0§Right now the `filter_expression` defined on Remote Settings experiment recipes is being processed by both `RemoteSettings` and `ASRouterTargeting` (via the RemoteSettingsExperimentLoader). This isn't ideal – we should probably rename this field to prevent conflicts or stop using `ASRouterTargeting` for filtering.§316§1 § Right now the `filter_expression` defined on Remote Settings experiment recipes is being processed by both `RemoteSettings` and `ASRouterTargeting` (via the RemoteSettingsExperimentLoader). This isn't ideal – we should probably rename this field to prevent conflicts or stop using `ASRouterTargeting` for filtering. § 2020-04-21T01:16:06Z § 2020-04-23T10:06:42Z
